summary.long: 2 Chronicles is a book of the Old Testament.

verses.text: Solomon, son of David, strengthened his position over the kingdom. Yahweh his Elohim was with him and made him very powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon spoke to all Israel—to the commanders of regiments and battalions, judges, every prince, and the heads of Israel’s families.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon and the entire assembly went to the place of worship in Gibeon because Elohim’s tent of meeting was there. Moses, Yahweh’s servant, had made the tent in the desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (However, David had already brought Elohim’s ark from Kiriath Jearim to a place he had prepared for it. He had put up a tent for it in Jerusalem.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The bronze altar that Bezalel, son of Uri and grandson of Hur, had made was in front of Yahweh’s tent. There Solomon and the assembly worshiped Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Yahweh’s presence Solomon went to the bronze altar in front of the tent of meeting and sacrificed 1,000 burnt offerings on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: That night Elohim appeared to Solomon. He said, “What can I give you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon responded to Elohim, “You’ve shown great love to my father David, and you’ve made me king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, Yahweh Elohim, you’ve kept the promise you made to my father David. You’ve made me king of people who are as numerous as specks of dust on the ground.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Give me wisdom and knowledge so that I may lead these people. After all, who can judge this great people of yours?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elohim replied to Solomon, “I know this request is from your heart. You didn’t ask for riches, fortunes, honor, or the death of those who hate you. You didn’t even ask for a long life. Instead, you’ve asked for wisdom and knowledge to judge my people, over whom I made you king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So wisdom and knowledge will be given to you. I will also give you riches, fortunes, and honor like no other king before or after you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon went from the tent of meeting at the place of worship in Gibeon to Jerusalem. And he ruled Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon built up his army with chariots and war horses. He had 1,400 chariots and 12,000 war horses. He stationed some in chariot cities and others with himself in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made silver and gold as common in Jerusalem as stones, and he made cedars as plentiful as fig trees in the foothills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon’s horses were imported from Egypt and Kue. The king’s traders bought them from Kue for a fixed price.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They imported each chariot from Egypt for 15 pounds of silver and each horse for 6 ounces of silver. For the same price they obtained horses to export to all the Hittite and Aramean kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon gave orders to begin building the temple for Yahweh’s name and a royal palace for himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon drafted 70,000 men to carry heavy loads, 80,000 to quarry stones in the mountains, and 3,600 foremen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon sent word to King Huram of Tyre by saying, “Do what you did for my father David. You sent him cedar so that he could build a palace to live in.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I want to build the temple for the name of Yahweh my Elohim. I want to dedicate it to him, burn sweet-smelling incense in his presence, and have rows of bread there continually. I want to sacrifice burnt offerings every morning and evening, on weekly worship days, New Moon Festivals, and during the annual festivals appointed by Yahweh our Elohim. (These festivals are always to be celebrated by Israel.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The temple I am building will be great because our Elohim is greater than all other gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But who is able to build him a temple when heaven itself, the highest heaven, cannot hold him? Who am I to build him a temple except as a place to sacrifice in his presence?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Send me a man who has the skill to work with gold, silver, bronze, and iron as well as purple, dark red, and violet cloth. He should know how to make engravings with the skilled men whom my father David provided for me in Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Send me cedar, cypress, and sandalwood from Lebanon. I know that your servants are skilled Lebanese lumberjacks. My workers will work with your workers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They’ll prepare plenty of lumber for me, because the temple I want to build will be large and astonishing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will give your lumberjacks 120,000 bushels of ground wheat, 120,000 bushels of barley, 200,000 gallons of wine, and 200,000 gallons of olive oil.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Huram of Tyre responded to Solomon by sending a letter that said, “Because Yahweh loves his people, he made you their king.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Huram added, “May Yahweh Elohim of Israel be praised. He made the heavens and the earth and has given King David a wise son who has insight and intelligence and can build Yahweh’s temple and a royal palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And now, I’m sending a man with skill and intelligence—Huram Abi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was the son of a woman from the tribe of Dan, and his father is a native of Tyre. Huram knows how to work with gold, silver, bronze, iron, stone, wood, purple, violet, and dark red cloth, and linen. He also knows how to make all kinds of engravings and follow any set of plans that will be given to him. He can work with your skilled workmen and the skilled workmen of His Majesty David, your father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Your Majesty may now send the wheat, barley, olive oil, and wine he promised the workers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We will cut all the lumber you need in Lebanon. Then we will make rafts out of it and send them to you in Joppa by sea. You can take it from there to Jerusalem.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon counted all the men who were foreigners in the land of Israel, as his father David had counted them. Solomon counted 153,600 foreigners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made 70,000 of them carry heavy loads, 80,000 of them quarry stone in the mountains, and 3,600 of them supervise the work as foremen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon began to build Yahweh’s temple in Jerusalem on Mount Moriah, where Yahweh appeared to his father David. There David had prepared the site on the threshing floor of Ornan the Jebusite.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He began to build on the second day in the second month of the fourth year of his reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is how Solomon laid the foundation to build Elohim’s temple. It was 90 feet long and 30 feet wide. (They used the old standard measurement.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The entrance hall in front of the main room was 30 feet wide (the same as the width of the temple) and 30 feet high. He covered its inside walls with pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He paneled the larger building with cypress, overlaid it with fine gold, and decorated it with designs in the form of palm trees and chains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He covered the building with gems to beautify it and used gold from Parvaim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also overlaid the building, the rafters, the threshold, the walls, and the doors with gold, and he carved angels into the walls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made the most holy place. It was as long as the temple was wide, 30 feet long. It was also 30 feet wide. He overlaid it with 45,000 pounds of fine gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The gold nails weighed 20 ounces. He also overlaid the upper rooms with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the most holy place he made two sculptured angels and covered them with gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The combined length of the angels’ wings was 30 feet. A wing of one of the angels was 7½ feet long and touched the wall of the building. Its other wing was 7½ feet long and touched one wing of the other.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The wing of the other one of the angels was 7½ feet long and touched the other wall of the building. Its other wing was 7½ feet long and touched the wing of the first. So the angels’ combined wingspan was 30 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They stood on their feet and faced the main hall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon made the canopy of violet, purple, and dark red cloth and of linen and decorated it with angels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made two pillars for the front of the temple. They were 53 feet long, and the capital on each pillar was 7½ feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made chains for the inner room and also put them on the capitals. He made 100 pomegranates and put them on the chains.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set up the pillars in front of the temple, one on the right and the other on the left. He named the one on the right Jachin [He Establishes] and the one on the left Boaz [In Him Is Strength].
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made a bronze altar 30 feet long, 30 feet wide, and 15 feet high.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Huram made a pool from cast metal. It was 15 feet in diameter. It was round, 7½ feet high, and had a circumference of 45 feet.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Under the rim were two rows of figurines shaped like bulls all around the 45-foot circumference of the pool. They were cast in metal when the pool was cast.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The pool was set on 12 metal bulls. Three bulls faced north, three faced west, three faced south, and three faced east. The pool was set on them, and their hindquarters were toward the center of the pool.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The pool was three inches thick. Its rim was like the rim of a cup, shaped like a lily’s bud. It held 18,000 gallons.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Huram also made ten basins for washing and put five on the south side and five on the north side. The priests rinsed the meat prepared for the burnt offerings in them. They used the pool to wash themselves.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Huram made ten gold lamp stands according to their specifications and put them in the temple, five on the south side and five on the north side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made ten tables and put them in the temple, five on the south side and five on the north side. And he made 100 gold bowls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made the priests’ courtyard and the large courtyard and its doors. He covered the doors with bronze.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set the pool on the south side in the southeast corner.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Huram also made the pots, shovels, and bowls.
So Huram finished the work for King Solomon in Elohim’s temple:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 2 pillars, bowl-shaped capitals on top of the 2 pillars, and 2 sets of filigree to cover the 2 bowl-shaped capitals on top of the pillars,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 400 pomegranates for the 2 sets of filigree (2 rows of pomegranates for each filigree to cover the 2 bowl-shaped capitals on the pillars),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 10 stands and 10 basins on the stands,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: 1 pool and the 12 bulls under it,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: pots, shovels, and three-pronged forks. Huram made all of them out of polished bronze for Yahweh’s temple at King Solomon’s request.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king cast them in foundries in the Jordan Valley between Succoth and Zeredah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon made so many of these products that no one tried to determine how much the bronze weighed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon made all the furnishings for Elohim’s temple: the gold altar, the gold tables on which the bread of the presence was placed,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: lamp stands and lamps of pure gold (to burn as directed in front of the inner room),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: flowers, lamps, pure gold tongs,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: snuffers, basins, dishes, incense burners of pure gold, the gold entrance to the temple, the gold doors of the inner room (the most holy place), and the gold doors of the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the work Solomon did on Yahweh’s temple was finished. He brought the holy things that had belonged to his father David—the silver, gold, and all the utensils—and put them in the storerooms of Elohim’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon assembled the respected leaders of Israel, all the heads of the tribes, and the leaders of the Israelite families. They came to Jerusalem to take the ark of Yahweh’s promise from the City of David (that is, Zion).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men of Israel gathered around the king at the Festival of Booths in the seventh month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the leaders of Israel had arrived, the Levites picked up the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought the ark, the tent of meeting, and all the holy utensils in it to the temple. The priests and the Levites carried them
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: while King Solomon and the whole assembly from Israel were offering countless sheep and cattle sacrifices in front of the ark.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests brought the ark of Yahweh’s promise to its place in the inner room of the temple (the most holy place) under the wings of the angels.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The angels’ outstretched wings were over the place where the ark rested so that the angels became a covering above the ark and its poles.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The poles were so long that their ends could be seen in the holy place by anyone standing in front of the inner room, but they couldn’t be seen outside. (They are still there today.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was nothing in the ark except the two tablets Moses placed there at Horeb, where Yahweh made a promise to the Israelites after they left Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the priests who were present had performed the ceremonies to make themselves holy to God without regard to staying in their divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the Levites who were musicians—Asaph, Heman, Jeduthun, their sons, and their relatives—were dressed in fine linen and stood east of the altar with cymbals, harps, and lyres. With the musicians were 120 priests blowing trumpets. When the priests left the holy place,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the trumpeters and singers praised and thanked Yahweh in unison. Accompanied by trumpets, cymbals, and other musical instruments, they sang in praise to Yahweh: “He is good; his mercy endures forever.” Then Yahweh’s temple was filled with a cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests couldn’t serve because of the cloud. Yahweh’s glory filled Elohim’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon said, “Yahweh said he would live in a dark cloud.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I have built you a high temple, a home for you to live in permanently.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king turned around and blessed the whole assembly from Israel while they were standing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Thanks be to Yahweh Elohim of Israel. With his mouth he made a promise to my father David; with his hand he carried it out. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘Ever since I brought my people Israel out of Egypt, I didn’t choose any city from the tribes of Israel as a place to build a temple for my name. And I didn’t choose any man to be prince over my people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But now I’ve chosen Jerusalem to be a place for my name; I’ve chosen David to rule my people Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “My father David had his heart set on building a temple for the name of Yahweh Elohim of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, Yahweh said to my father David, ‘Since you had your heart set on building a temple for my name, your intentions were good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you must not build the temple. Instead, your own son will build the temple for my name.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh has kept the promise he made. I’ve taken my father David’s place, and I sit on the throne of Israel as Yahweh promised. I’ve built the temple for the name of Yahweh Elohim of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I’ve put the ark which contains Yahweh’s promise to Israel there.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the presence of the entire assembly of Israel, Solomon stood in front of Yahweh’s altar. He stretched out his hands to pray.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (Solomon had made a bronze platform 7½ feet long, 7½ feet wide, and 4½ feet high. He put it in the middle of the courtyard. He stood on the platform, knelt in front of the entire assembly, and stretched out his hands toward heaven.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He said,
“Yahweh Elohim of Israel,
    there is no god like you in heaven or on earth.
You keep your promise of mercy to your servants,
    who obey you wholeheartedly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
You have kept your promise to my father David, your servant.
    With your mouth you promised it.
    With your hand you carried it out as it is today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Now, Yahweh Elohim of Israel,
    keep your promise to my father David, your servant.
        You said, ‘You will never fail to have an heir
            sitting in front of me on the throne of Israel
                if your descendants are faithful to me
                    as you have been faithful to me.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“So now, Yahweh Elohim of Israel,
    may the promise you made to David, your servant, come true.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Does Elohim really live on earth with people?
    If heaven itself, the highest heaven, cannot hold you,
    then how can this temple that I have built?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Nevertheless, my Yahweh Elohim, please pay attention to my prayer for mercy.
Listen to my cry for help as I pray to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Day and night may your eyes be on this temple,
    the place about which you said your name will be there.
Listen to me as I pray toward this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hear the plea for mercy
    that your people Israel and I pray toward this place.
Hear us in heaven, the place where you live.
Hear and forgive.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If anyone sins against another person
    and is required to take an oath
        and comes to take the oath in front of your altar in this temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then hear that person in heaven, take action, and make a decision.
    Repay the guilty person with the proper punishment,
        but declare the innocent person innocent.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“An enemy may defeat your people Israel
    because they have sinned against you.
        But when your people turn, praise your name, pray,
            and plead with you in this temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then hear them in heaven, forgive the sins of your people Israel,
    and bring them back to the land
        that you gave to them and their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“When the sky is shut and there’s no rain
    because they are sinning against you
        and they pray toward this place, praise your name,
            and turn away from their sin because you made them suffer,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then hear them in heaven.
    Forgive the sins of your servants, your people Israel.
    Teach them the proper way to live.
        Then send rain on the land,
            which you gave to your people as an inheritance.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“There may be famine in the land.
Plant diseases, heat waves, funguses, locusts,
    or grasshoppers may destroy crops.
Enemies may blockade Israel’s city gates.
During every plague or sickness
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
hear every prayer for mercy
    made by one person or by all the people in Israel,
        all who know suffering or pain,
            who stretch out their hands toward this temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hear them in heaven, where you live.
    Forgive them, and give each person the proper reply.
        (You know what is in their hearts,
            because you alone know what is in people’s hearts.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then, as long as they live in the land that you gave to our ancestors,
    they will fear you and follow you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“People who are not Israelites
    will come from distant countries because of your great name,
        mighty hand, and powerful arm.
When they come to pray facing this temple,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then hear them in heaven, the place where you live.
    Do everything they ask you
        so that all the people of the world may know your name
            and fear you like your people Israel
            and learn that this temple which I built bears your name.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“When your people go to war against their enemies
    (wherever you may send them)
        and they pray to you toward this city you have chosen
            and the temple I built for your name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then hear their prayer for mercy in heaven,
    and do what is right for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“They may sin against you.
    (No one is sinless.)
    You may become angry with them and hand them over to an enemy
        who takes them to another country as captives,
            whether it is far or near.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
If they come to their senses,
    are sorry for what they’ve done,
        and plead with you in the land where they are captives,
            saying, ‘We have sinned. We have done wrong.
                We have been wicked,’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
if they change their attitude toward you
    in the land where they are captives,
if they pray to you
    toward the land that you gave their ancestors,
        and the city you have chosen,
        and the temple I have built for your name,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then in heaven, the place where you live, hear their prayer for mercy.
    Do what is right for them.
        Forgive your people, who have sinned against you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Finally, my Elohim, may your eyes be open and your ears attentive
    to the prayers offered in this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Now arise, and come to your resting place, Yahweh Elohim—
    you and the ark of your power.
Clothe your priests, Yahweh Elohim, with salvation.
Let your godly ones rejoice in what is good.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Yahweh Elohim, do not reject your anointed one.
Remember your mercy to your servant David!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Solomon finished praying, fire came down from heaven and consumed the burnt offerings and the other sacrifices, and Yahweh’s glory filled the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests couldn’t go into Yahweh’s temple because Yahweh’s glory had filled Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When all the Israelites saw the fire come down and Yahweh’s glory on the temple, they knelt down with their faces on the pavement. They worshiped and praised Yahweh, by saying, “He is good; his mercy endures forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king and all the people offered sacrifices to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon offered 22,000 cattle and 120,000 sheep as sacrifices to the Lord. So the king and all the people dedicated Elohim’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests were standing at their posts. So were the Levites who had Yahweh’s musical instruments which King David made for praising Yahweh with “his mercy endures forever” and which he used to offer praise. The priests were opposite the Levites blowing trumpets while all Israel was standing there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon designated the courtyard in front of Yahweh’s temple as a holy place. He sacrificed the burnt offerings, grain offerings, and the fat because the bronze altar that he had made and that was in front of the Lord was not able to hold all of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time Solomon and all Israel celebrated the Festival of Booths. A very large crowd had come from the territory between the border of Hamath and the River of Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the eighth day there was an assembly. They had observed the dedication of the altar for seven days and celebrated the festival for another seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the twenty-third day of the seventh month, Solomon dismissed the people to their tents. They rejoiced with cheerful hearts for all the blessings Yahweh had given David, Solomon, and his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon finished Yahweh’s temple and the royal palace and completed everything he had in mind for Yahweh’s temple and his own palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Then Yahweh appeared to him at night. He said to Solomon,
“I have heard your prayer
    and have chosen this place for myself as a temple for sacrifices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I may shut the sky so that there is no rain,
    or command grasshoppers to devour the countryside,
    or send an epidemic among my people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
However, if my people, who are called by my name,
    will humble themselves,
    pray, search for me, and turn from their evil ways,
        then I will hear their prayer from heaven, forgive their sins,
    and heal their country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
My eyes will be open,
    and my ears will pay attention to those prayers at this place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
I have chosen and declared this temple holy
    so that my name may be placed there forever.
        My eyes and my heart will always be there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“If you will be faithful to me as your father David was,
    do everything I command,
        and obey my laws and rules,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then I will establish your royal dynasty
    as I said in a promise to your father David,
        ‘You will never fail to have an heir ruling Israel.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
But if you and your descendants turn away from me
    and abandon my commands and laws that I gave you,
        and follow and serve other gods and worship them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
then I will uproot Israel from the land I gave them.
    I will reject this temple that I declared holy for my name.
    I will make it an example
        and an object of ridicule for all the people of the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Everyone passing by this impressive temple will be appalled.
    They will ask,
        ‘Why did Yahweh do these things to this land and this temple?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
They will answer themselves,
    ‘They abandoned Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors,
        who brought them out of Egypt.
        They adopted other gods, worshiped, and served them.
        That is why he brought this disaster on them.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It took Solomon 20 years to build Yahweh’s house and his own house.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He rebuilt the cities Huram gave him, and he had Israelites live in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon went to Hamath Zobah and conquered it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He rebuilt Tadmor in the desert and built all the storage cities in Hamath.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He rebuilt Upper Beth Horon and Lower Beth Horon into cities fortified with walls, double-door gates, and bars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also rebuilt Baalath and all the storage cities that he owned. He built all the cities for his chariots, all the cities for his war horses, and whatever else he wanted to build in Jerusalem, Lebanon, or the entire territory that he governed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Hittites, Perizzites, Hivites, and Jebusites had been left in the land because the Israelites had not been able to destroy them. They were not Israelites,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: but they had descendants who were still in the land. Solomon drafted them for slave labor. (They are still slaves today.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Solomon didn’t make any of the Israelites slaves for his projects. Instead, they were the soldiers, officers, generals, and commanders of his chariot and cavalry units.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the officers in charge of King Solomon’s projects: 250 foremen for the people who did the work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon brought Pharaoh’s daughter from the City of David to a palace he had built for her. He said, “My wife will not live in the palace of King David of Israel because these places where Yahweh’s ark has come are holy.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon sacrificed burnt offerings to Yahweh on Yahweh’s altar that he built in front of the entrance hall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sacrificed every day, on weekly worship days, on the New Moon Festivals, and on the three annual festivals (the Festival of Unleavened Bread, the Festival of Weeks, and the Festival of Booths) as Moses had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As Solomon’s father David had directed, he set up the divisions of priests for their service and the divisions of Levites for their appointed places. The Levites were to lead in praising the Lord and to serve beside the priests by doing whatever needed to be done each day. Solomon also set up divisions of doorkeepers at every gate because this is what David, the man of Elohim, had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one neglected the king’s orders to the priests or the Levites in any matter, including the temple’s finances.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All of Solomon’s work was carried out from the day the foundation of Yahweh’s temple was laid until it was completed. Yahweh’s temple was now finished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Solomon went to the coast near Ezion Geber and Elath in Edom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Huram sent his own servants and his experienced sailors with ships to Solomon. They went with Solomon’s servants to Ophir, got 33,750 pounds of gold, and brought it to King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The queen of Sheba heard about Solomon’s reputation. So she came to Jerusalem to test him with riddles. She arrived with a large group of servants, with camels carrying spices, a large quantity of gold, and precious stones. When she came to Solomon, she talked to him about everything she had on her mind.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon answered all her questions. No question was too difficult for Solomon to answer.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the queen of Sheba saw Solomon’s wisdom, the palace he built,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: the food on his table, his officers’ seating arrangement, the organization of his officials and the uniforms they wore, his cupbearers and their uniforms, and the burnt offerings that he sacrificed at Yahweh’s temple, she was breathless.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She told the king, “What I heard in my country about your words and your wisdom is true!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But I didn’t believe the reports until I came and saw it with my own eyes. I wasn’t even told about half of the extent of your wisdom. You’ve surpassed the stories I’ve heard.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: How blessed your men must be! How blessed these servants of yours must be because they are always stationed in front of you and listen to your wisdom!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Thank Yahweh your Elohim, who is pleased with you. He has put you on his throne to be king on behalf of Yahweh your Elohim. Because of your Elohim’s love for the people of Israel, he has established them permanently and made you king over them so that you would maintain justice and righteousness.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She gave the king 9,000 pounds of gold, a very large quantity of spices, and precious stones. Never was there such a large quantity of spices in Israel as those that the queen of Sheba gave King Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Huram’s servants and Solomon’s servants who brought gold from Ophir also brought sandalwood and precious stones.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With the sandalwood the king made gateways to Yahweh’s temple and the royal palace, and lyres and harps for the singers. No one had ever seen anything like them in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon gave the queen of Sheba anything she wanted, whatever she asked for, more than what she had brought him. Then she and her servants went back to her country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The gold that came to Solomon in one year weighed 49,950 pounds,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: not counting the gold which the merchants and traders brought. All the Arab kings and governors of the land also brought gold and silver to Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Solomon made 200 large shields of hammered gold, using 15 pounds of gold on each shield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made 300 small shields of hammered gold, using 7½ pounds of gold on each shield. The king put them in the hall named the Forest of Lebanon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king also made a large ivory throne and covered it with pure gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Six steps led to the throne, which had a gold footstool attached to it. There were armrests on both sides of the seat. Two lions stood beside the armrests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Twelve lions stood on six steps, one on each side. Nothing like this had been made for any other kingdom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All King Solomon’s cups were gold, and all the utensils for the hall named the Forest of Lebanon were fine gold. (Silver wasn’t considered valuable in Solomon’s time.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king had ships going to Tarshish with Huram’s sailors. Once every three years the Tarshish ships would bring gold, silver, ivory, apes, and monkeys.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In wealth and wisdom King Solomon was greater than all the other kings of the world.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the kings of the world wanted to listen to the wisdom that Elohim gave Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So everyone who came brought him gifts: articles of silver and gold, clothing, weapons, spices, horses, and mules. This happened year after year.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon had 4,000 stalls for horses and chariots, and 12,000 war horses. He stationed some in chariot cities and others with himself in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ruled all the kings from the Euphrates River to the country of the Philistines and as far as the Egyptian border.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king made silver as common in Jerusalem as stones, and he made cedars as plentiful as fig trees in the foothills.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Horses were imported for Solomon from Egypt and from all other countries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aren’t the rest of Solomon’s acts from first to last written in the records of Nathan the prophet, in the prophecy of Ahijah from Shiloh, and in Iddo the seer’s visions about Jeroboam (son of Nebat)?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon ruled in Jerusalem over all Israel for 40 years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Solomon lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried in the City of David. His son Rehoboam succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam went to Shechem because all Israel had gone to Shechem to make him king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam (Nebat’s son) was still in Egypt, where he had fled from King Solomon. When he heard about Rehoboam, he returned from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel sent for Jeroboam and invited him back. Jeroboam and all Israel went to speak to Rehoboam. They said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Your father made us carry a heavy burden. Reduce the hard work and lighten the heavy burden he put on us, and we will serve you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “Come back the day after tomorrow.” So the people left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam sought advice from the older leaders who had served his father Solomon while he was still alive. He asked, “What do you advise? How should I respond to these people?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They told him, “If you are good to these people and try to please them by speaking gently to them, then they will always be your servants.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he ignored the advice the older leaders gave him. He sought advice from the young men who had grown up with him and were serving him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He asked them, “What is your advice? How should we respond to these people who are asking me to lighten the burden my father put on them?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The young men who had grown up with him answered, “This is what you should tell them: ‘My little finger is heavier than my father’s whole body.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If my father put a heavy burden on you, I will add to it. If my father punished you with whips, I will punish you with scorpions.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jeroboam and all the people came back to Rehoboam two days later, as the king had instructed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king answered them harshly. He ignored the older leaders’ advice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He spoke to them as the young men advised. He said, “If my father made your burden heavy, I will add to it. If my father punished you with whips, I will use scorpions.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king refused to listen to the people because Yahweh was directing these events to carry out the promise he had made to Jeroboam (Nebat’s son) through Ahijah from Shiloh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When all Israel saw that the king refused to listen to them, the people answered the king,
“What share do we have in David’s kingdom?
We won’t receive an inheritance from Jesse’s son.
    Everyone to his own tent, Israel!
    Now look after your own house, David!”
So all Israel went home to their own tents.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Rehoboam ruled the Israelites who lived in the cities of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Rehoboam sent Hadoram to the Israelites. He was in charge of forced labor, but they stoned him to death. So King Rehoboam got on his chariot as fast as he could and fled to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel has rebelled against David’s dynasty to this day.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rehoboam came to Jerusalem, he gathered the people of Judah and Benjamin, 180,000 of the best soldiers, to fight against Israel and return the kingdom to Rehoboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Yahweh spoke his word to Shemaiah, the man of Elohim. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Speak to Judah’s King Rehoboam, son of Solomon, and all Israel in Judah and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Yahweh says: Don’t wage war against your relatives. Everyone, go home. What has happened is my doing.” So they obeyed the word of Yahweh. They turned back from their attack on Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam lived in Jerusalem and built fortified cities in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He rebuilt Bethlehem, Etam, Tekoa,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Beth Zur, Soco, Adullam,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Gath, Mareshah, Ziph,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Adoraim, Lachish, Azekah,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zorah, Aijalon, and Hebron. These were fortified cities in Judah and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He strengthened them and put army officers with reserves of food, olive oil, and wine in them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In each city he stored shields and spears. He made the cities very secure. So Rehoboam held on to Judah and Benjamin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests and Levites in every region of Israel sided with Rehoboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests abandoned their land and property and went to Judah and Jerusalem because Jeroboam and his descendants rejected them as Yahweh’s priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, Jeroboam appointed his own priests for the illegal worship sites and the goat and calf statues he had made as idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: People from every tribe of Israel who were determined to seek Yahweh Elohim of Israel followed the Levitical priests to Jerusalem to sacrifice to Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they strengthened the kingdom of Judah by supporting Rehoboam, son of Solomon, for three years. During those three years they lived the way David and Solomon had lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam married Mahalath, daughter of Jerimoth. (Jerimoth was the son of David and Abihail. Abihail was the daughter of Eliab, son of Jesse.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Mahalath gave birth to the following sons: Jeush, Shemariah, and Zaham.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After marrying Mahalath, he married Maacah, Absalom’s granddaughter. She gave birth to Abijah, Attai, Ziza, and Shelomith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam loved Maacah, Absalom’s granddaughter, more than all his other wives and concubines. (He had 18 wives and 60 concubines. He fathered 28 sons and 60 daughters.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam appointed Abijah, son of Maacah, as family head and prince among his brothers. By doing this, Rehoboam could make him king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He wisely placed his sons in every region of Judah and Benjamin, in every fortified city. He gave them allowances and obtained many wives for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Rehoboam had established his kingdom and made himself strong, he and all Israel abandoned Yahweh’s teachings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the fifth year of Rehoboam’s reign, King Shishak of Egypt attacked Jerusalem. This happened because all Israel was not loyal to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shishak had 1,200 chariots, 60,000 horses, and an army of countless Libyans, Sukkites, and Sudanese from Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He captured the fortified cities in Judah and then came to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The prophet Shemaiah came to Rehoboam and the leaders of Judah who had gathered in Jerusalem because of Shishak. Shemaiah said to them, “This is what Yahweh says: You have abandoned me, so I will abandon you. I will hand you over to Shishak.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the commanders of Israel and the king humbled themselves. “Yahweh is right!” they said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Yahweh saw that they had humbled themselves, Yahweh spoke his word to Shemaiah: “They have humbled themselves. I will not destroy them. In a little while I will give them an escape. I will not use Shishak to pour my anger on Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they will become his servants so that they can learn the difference between serving me and serving foreign kings.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Shishak of Egypt attacked Jerusalem and took the treasures from Yahweh’s temple and the royal palace. He took them all. He took the gold shields Solomon had made.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Rehoboam made bronze shields to replace them and put them by the entrance to the royal palace, where the captains of the guards were stationed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the king went into Yahweh’s temple, guards carried the shields and then returned them to the guardroom.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Rehoboam humbled himself, Yahweh was no longer angry with him and didn’t completely destroy him. So things went well in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Rehoboam strengthened his position in Jerusalem and ruled. He was 41 years old when he began to rule. He ruled for 17 years in Jerusalem, the city that Yahweh chose from all the tribes of Israel, the city where Yahweh put his name. (Rehoboam’s mother was an Ammonite woman named Naamah.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did evil things because he was not serious about dedicating himself to serving Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Aren’t the events concerning Rehoboam from first to last written in the records of the prophet Shemaiah and the records of the seer Iddo in the genealogies? There was war between Rehoboam and Jeroboam as long as they lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Rehoboam lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried in the City of David. His son Abijah succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighteenth year of the reign of Jeroboam, Abijah began to rule Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
He ruled for three years in Jerusalem. His mother was named Micaiah, daughter of Uriel from Gibeah.
There was war between Abijah and Jeroboam.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijah prepared for battle with an army of 400,000 of the best soldiers, while Jeroboam arranged to oppose him with 800,000 of the best professional soldiers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim in the mountains of Ephraim. He called out, “Jeroboam and all Israel, listen to me!
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t you know that Yahweh Elohim of Israel gave the kingdom of Israel to David and his descendants forever in a permanent promise?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jeroboam (Nebat’s son) rebelled against his master. He had been the servant of David’s son Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Worthless, good-for-nothing men gathered around him. They opposed Rehoboam, son of Solomon, when Rehoboam was too young and inexperienced to challenge them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Do you now intend to challenge Yahweh’s kingdom, which has been placed in the hands of David’s descendants? You are a large crowd, and you have the gold calves that Jeroboam made to be your gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You forced out Yahweh’s priests who were Aaron’s descendants, and you forced out the Levites so that you could appoint your own priests, as the people in foreign countries do. Anyone who has a young bull and seven rams can be ordained as a priest of nonexistent gods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “However, Yahweh is our Elohim. We haven’t abandoned him. The priests who serve Yahweh are Aaron’s descendants, and the Levites assist them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They sacrifice burnt offerings to Yahweh every morning and every evening. They offer sweet-smelling incense and rows of bread on the clean table. The lamps on the gold lamp stand burn every evening. We’re following the instructions Yahweh our Elohim gave us, but you have abandoned him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elohim is with us as our leader. His priests will sound their trumpets to call the army to fight you. Men of Israel, don’t wage war against Yahweh Elohim of your ancestors. You won’t succeed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jeroboam had set an ambush to attack them from behind. So Jeroboam’s army was in front of Judah, and the ambush was behind them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Judah’s soldiers looked around, the battle was in front of them and behind them. They cried out to Yahweh, the priests blew the trumpets,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the men of Judah shouted. When they shouted, Elohim attacked Jeroboam and all Israel in front of Abijah and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites fled from Judah’s army, and Elohim handed them over to Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Abijah and his men defeated them decisively, and 500,000 of the best men of Israel were killed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Israelites were humbled at that time, and the men of Judah won because they trusted Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijah pursued Jeroboam and captured some of his cities: Bethel and its villages, Jeshanah and its villages, and Ephron and its villages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeroboam never regained power during Abijah’s time. Yahweh caused Jeroboam to become sick, and Jeroboam died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Abijah became strong. He married 14 wives and fathered 22 sons and 16 daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything else about Abijah—how he lived and what he said—is written in the history by the prophet Iddo.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Abijah lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried in the City of David. His son Asa succeeded him as king. In Asa’s time the land had peace for ten years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa did what Yahweh his Elohim considered good and right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He got rid of the altars of foreign gods, broke down the sacred stones, and cut down the poles dedicated to the goddess Asherah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told the people of Judah to dedicate their lives to serving Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors and follow his teachings and commands.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He got rid of the illegal places of worship and the altars for incense in all the cities of Judah. The kingdom was at peace during his reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built fortified cities in Judah because the land had peace. There was no war during those years because Yahweh gave him a time of peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Asa told Judah, “Let’s build these cities and make walls around them with towers and doors that can be barred. The country is still ours because we have dedicated our lives to serving Yahweh our Elohim. We have dedicated our lives to him, and he has surrounded us with peace.” So they built the cities, and everything went well.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa had an army of 300,000 Judeans who were armed with large shields and spears and 280,000 Benjaminites who were armed with small shields and bows. All of these men were good fighting men.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Zerah from Sudan came with 1,000,000 men and 300 chariots to attack Asa. Zerah got as far as Mareshah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa went to confront him, and the two armies set up their battle lines in the Zephathah Valley at Mareshah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa called on Yahweh his Elohim. He said, “Yahweh, there is no one except you who can help those who are not strong so that they can fight against a large army. Help us, Yahweh our Elohim, because we are depending on you. In your name we go against this large crowd. You are Yahweh our Elohim. Don’t let anyone successfully oppose you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh attacked the Sudanese army in front of Asa and Judah. The Sudanese army fled.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa and his troops pursued them as far as Gerar. Many of the Sudanese died in battle. As a result, the Sudanese army couldn’t fight again. It was crushed in front of Yahweh and his army. Yahweh’s army captured a lot of goods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It attacked all the cities around Gerar because the cities were afraid of Yahweh. The army looted all the cities because there were many things to take.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: It also attacked those who were letting their cattle graze and captured many sheep and camels. Then it returned to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ruach Elohim came to Azariah, son of Oded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Azariah went to Asa and said to him, “Listen to me, Asa and all you men from Judah and Benjamin. Yahweh is with you when you are with him. If you will dedicate your lives to serving him, he will accept you. But if you abandon him, he will abandon you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For a long time Israel was without the true Elohim, without a priest who taught correctly, and without Moses’ Teachings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when they were in trouble, they turned to Yahweh Elohim of Israel. When they searched for him, he let them find him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At those times no one could come and go in peace, because everyone living in the land had a lot of turmoil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One nation crushed another nation; one city crushed another. Elohim had tormented them with every kind of trouble.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But you must remain strong and not become discouraged. Your actions will be rewarded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Asa heard the prophet Oded’s words of prophecy, he was encouraged and put away the detestable idols from all of Judah, Benjamin, and the cities he had captured in the mountains of Ephraim. He also repaired Yahweh’s altar in front of Yahweh’s entrance hall.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Asa gathered all the people from Judah and Benjamin and the foreigners who had come from Ephraim, Manasseh, and Simeon. (Many of them had come to him from Israel when they saw that Asa’s Elohim, Yahweh, was with him.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the third month of the fifteenth year of Asa’s reign, they gathered in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On that day they sacrificed to Yahweh a part of the loot they had brought with them: 700 cattle and 7,000 sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They made an agreement with one another to dedicate their lives to serving Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors with all their heart and soul.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All people (young or old, male or female) who refused to dedicate their lives to Yahweh Elohim of Israel were to be killed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa and the people swore their oath to Yahweh with shouts, singing, and the blowing of trumpets and rams’ horns.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Judah were overjoyed because of the oath, since they took the oath wholeheartedly. They took great pleasure in looking for Yahweh, and he let them find him. So Yahweh surrounded them with peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Asa also removed his grandmother Maacah from the position of queen mother because she made a statue of the repulsive goddess Asherah. Asa cut the statue down, crushed it, and burned it in the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Although the illegal worship sites in Israel were not taken down, Asa remained committed to the Lord his entire life.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought into Elohim’s temple the silver, the gold, and the utensils he and his father had set apart as holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There was no war until the thirty-fifth year of Asa’s reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the thirty-sixth year of Asa’s reign, King Baasha of Israel invaded Judah and fortified Ramah to keep anyone from going to or coming from King Asa of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Asa brought out all the silver and gold that was left in the treasuries of Yahweh’s temple and the royal palace. He sent them to Damascus to Aram’s King Benhadad.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “There’s a treaty between you and me as there was between your father and my father. I’m sending you silver and gold. Now break your treaty with King Baasha of Israel so that he will leave me alone.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Benhadad did what King Asa requested. He sent his generals and their armies to attack the cities of Israel. He conquered Ijon, Dan, Abel Maim, and all the storage cities in the territory of Naphtali.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Baasha heard the news, he stopped fortifying Ramah and abandoned his work on it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Asa took everyone in Judah to Ramah. He made them carry the stones and lumber from Ramah. Baasha had been using those to fortify the city. Asa used the materials to fortify Geba in Benjamin and Mizpah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time the seer Hanani came to King Asa of Judah and said to him, “Because you depended on the king of Syria and did not depend on Yahweh your Elohim, the army of the king of Aram has escaped your grasp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Weren’t the Sudanese and Libyans a large army with many chariots and drivers? But when you depended on Yahweh, he handed them over to you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh’s eyes scan the whole world to find those whose hearts are committed to him and to strengthen them. You acted foolishly in this matter. So from now on, you will have to fight wars.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa was furious at the seer. He was so angry with Hanani that he put Hanani in prison. Asa also oppressed some of the people at that time in his reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything about Asa from first to last is written in the Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the thirty-ninth year of his reign, Asa got a foot disease that became progressively worse. Instead of asking Yahweh for help, he went to doctors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa lay down in death with his ancestors. He died in the forty-first year of his reign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They buried him in the tomb that he had prepared for himself in the City of David. They laid him on a bed full of spices and blended perfumes. And they burned a bonfire in his honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Asa’s son Jehoshaphat succeeded him as king. Jehoshaphat strengthened himself to wage war against Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He put troops in all the fortified cities of Judah and placed military posts in Judah and in the cities of Ephraim that his father Asa had captured.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh was with Jehoshaphat, who lived in the old way like his ancestor David. Jehoshaphat didn’t dedicate his life to serving other gods—the Baals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, he dedicated his life to his ancestor’s Elohim and lived by Elohim’s commands. Jehoshaphat did not do what Israel was doing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Yahweh established Jehoshaphat’s power over the kingdom. All the people of Judah gave gifts to Jehoshaphat, and he had a lot of riches and honor.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had the confidence to live the way Yahweh wanted him to live. He also got rid of the illegal places of worship and poles dedicated to the goddess Asherah in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the third year of his reign, he sent his officers Ben Hail, Obadiah, Zechariah, Nethanel, and Micaiah to teach in the cities of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: With them were the Levites Shemaiah, Nethaniah, Zebadiah, Asahel, Shemiramoth, Jehonathan, Adonijah, Tobijah, Tob Adonijah, and the priests Elishama and Jehoram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They taught in Judah. They had the Book of Yahweh’s Teachings with them when they taught the people in all the cities of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Fear of Yahweh came to all the kingdoms around Judah. As a result, they didn’t wage war against Jehoshaphat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some of the Philistines brought gifts and silver as taxes. The Arabs also brought him flocks: 7,700 rams and 7,700 male goats.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Jehoshaphat became more and more powerful. He built fortresses and cities where supplies were stored in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had large supplies of food in the cities of Judah and an army of professional soldiers with him in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The following is a breakdown of these soldiers. They are listed by families. Judah’s regimental commanders were Commander Adnah (with 300,000 fighting men),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: next to him Commander Jehohanan (with 280,000),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and next to him Amasiah, Zichri’s son, who volunteered to serve Yahweh (with 200,000 fighting men).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: From Benjamin there was the fighting man Eliada (with 200,000 armed men with bows and shields),
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and next to him was Jehozabad (with him was an army of 180,000 armed men).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the men who served the king in addition to those whom the king put in the fortified cities throughout Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat was wealthy and honorable and became Ahab’s in-law.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A few years later he went to visit Ahab in Samaria. Ahab slaughtered many sheep and cattle for a banquet in honor of Jehoshaphat and the people who were with him. And Ahab persuaded Jehoshaphat to attack Ramoth in Gilead with him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
King Ahab of Israel asked King Jehoshaphat of Judah, “Will you go with me to Ramoth in Gilead?”
Jehoshaphat told the king of Israel, “I will do what you do. My troops will do what your troops do. We will join your troops in battle.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Jehoshaphat said to the king of Israel, “But first, find out what the word of Yahweh is in this matter.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the king of Israel called 400 prophets together. He asked them, “Should we go to war against Ramoth in Gilead or not?”
“Go,” they said. “Elohim will hand over Ramoth to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoshaphat asked, “Isn’t there a prophet of Yahweh whom we could ask?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The king of Israel told Jehoshaphat, “We can ask Yahweh through Micaiah, son of Imla, but I hate him. Nothing he prophesies about me is good; it’s always evil.”
Jehoshaphat answered, “The king must not say that.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel called for an officer and said, “Quick! Get Micaiah, son of Imla!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah were dressed in royal robes and seated on thrones. They were sitting on the threshing floor at the entrance to the gate of Samaria. All the prophets were prophesying in front of them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah, son of Chenaanah, made iron horns and said, “This is what Yahweh says: With these horns you will push the Arameans to their destruction.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the other prophets made the same prophecy. They said, “Attack Ramoth in Gilead, and you will win. Yahweh will hand it over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The messenger who went to call Micaiah told him, “The prophets have all told the king the same good message. Make your message agree with their message. Say something good.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah answered, “I solemnly swear, as Yahweh lives, I will tell him whatever my Elohim says to me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
When he came to the king, the king asked him, “Micaiah, should we go to war against Ramoth in Gilead or not?”
Micaiah said, “Attack and you will win. They will be handed over to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king asked him, “How many times must I make you take an oath in Yahweh’s name to tell me nothing but the truth?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Micaiah said, “I saw Israel’s troops scattered in the hills like sheep without a shepherd. Yahweh said, ‘These sheep have no master. Let each one go home in peace.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, “Didn’t I tell you he wouldn’t prophesy anything good about me?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah added, “Then hear the word of Yahweh. I saw Yahweh sitting on his throne, and the entire army of heaven was standing on his right and his left.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh asked, ‘Who will deceive King Ahab of Israel so that he will attack and be killed at Ramoth in Gilead?’ Some answered one way, while others were saying something else.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“Then the Ruach stepped forward, stood in front of Yahweh, and said, ‘I will deceive him.’
“‘How?’ Yahweh asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
“The Ruach answered, ‘I will go out and be a spirit that tells lies through the mouths of all of Ahab’s prophets.’
“Yahweh said, ‘You will succeed in deceiving him. Go and do it.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “So Yahweh has put into the mouths of these prophets of yours a spirit that makes them tell lies. Yahweh has spoken evil about you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah, son of Chenaanah, went to Micaiah and struck him on the cheek. “Which way did the Ruach go when he left me to talk to you?” he asked.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah answered, “You will find out on the day you go into an inner room to hide.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel then said, “Send Micaiah back to Amon, the governor of the city, and to Joash, the prince.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Say, ‘This is what the king says: Put this man in prison, and feed him nothing but bread and water until I return home safely.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Micaiah said, “If you really do come back safely, then Yahweh wasn’t speaking through me. Pay attention to this, everyone!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king of Israel and King Jehoshaphat of Judah went to Ramoth in Gilead.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Israel told Jehoshaphat, “I will disguise myself and go into battle, but you should wear your royal robes.” So the king of Israel disguised himself and went into battle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Aram had given orders to the chariot commanders. He said, “Don’t fight anyone except the king of Israel.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the chariot commanders saw Jehoshaphat, they said, “He must be the king of Israel.” So they surrounded him in order to fight him. But when Jehoshaphat cried out, Yahweh helped him. Elohim drew them away from him,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and the chariot commanders realized that Jehoshaphat wasn’t the king of Israel. Then they turned away from him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: One man aimed his bow at random and hit the king of Israel between his scale armor and his breastplate. Ahab told the chariot driver, “Turn around, and get me away from these troops. I’m badly wounded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the battle got worse that day, and the king propped himself up in his chariot facing the Arameans until evening. At sundown he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Jehoshaphat of Judah returned safely to his home in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehu, son of the seer Hanani, asked King Jehoshaphat, “Why do you help wicked people and love those who hate Yahweh? Yahweh’s anger is directed toward you because you have done this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, you’ve done some good things: You’ve burned the Asherah poles in this country, and you’ve wholeheartedly dedicated your life to serving Elohim.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: While Jehoshaphat was living in Jerusalem, he regularly went to the people between Beersheba and the mountains of Ephraim. He brought the people back to Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He appointed judges in the country, in each fortified city of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told the judges, “Pay attention to what you’re doing. When you judge, you aren’t doing it for a human but for Yahweh. He will be with you when you hear a case.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: May you have the fear of Yahweh in you. Be careful about what you do. Yahweh our Elohim is never unjust. He is impartial and never takes bribes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In Jerusalem Jehoshaphat also appointed some Levites, priests, and family heads from Israel to administer Yahweh’s laws and decide cases. They lived in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He ordered them, “Do this wholeheartedly—with the fear of Yahweh and with faithfulness.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Warn your relatives living in other cities about every case they bring to you, even if the case involves bloodshed or commands, rules, or regulations derived from Moses’ Teachings. Then your relatives will not become guilty in front of Yahweh. Otherwise, he will become angry with you and your relatives. Do this, and you won’t be guilty of anything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now, the chief priest Amariah will be in charge of you in every matter involving Yahweh. Zebadiah, who is the son of Ishmael and the leader of the tribe of Judah, will be in charge of every matter involving the king. The Levites will serve as officers of the court. Be strong, and do your job. May Yahweh be with those who do right.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Later the Moabites, Ammonites, and some of the Meunites came to wage war against Jehoshaphat.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some men reported to Jehoshaphat, “A large crowd is coming against you from the other side of the Dead Sea, from Edom. The crowd is already in Hazazon Tamar” (also called En Gedi).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Frightened, Jehoshaphat decided to ask for Yahweh’s help. He announced a fast throughout Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Judah gathered to seek Yahweh’s help. They came from every city in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the new courtyard at Yahweh’s temple, Jehoshaphat stood in front of the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said, “Yahweh Elohim of our ancestors, aren’t you the Elohim in heaven? You rule all the kingdoms of the nations. You possess power and might, and no one can oppose you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Didn’t you, our Elohim, force those who were living in this country out of Israel’s way? Didn’t you give this country to the descendants of your friend Abraham to have permanently?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His descendants have lived in it and built a holy temple for your name in it. They said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘If evil comes in the form of war, flood, plague, or famine, we will stand in front of this temple and in front of you because your name is in this temple. We will cry out to you in our troubles, and you will hear us and save us.’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “The Ammonites, Moabites, and the people of Mount Seir have come here. However, you didn’t let Israel invade them when they came out of Egypt. The Israelites turned away from them and didn’t destroy them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They are now paying us back by coming to force us out of your land that you gave to us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You’re our Elohim. Won’t you judge them? We don’t have the strength to face this large crowd that is attacking us. We don’t know what to do, so we’re looking to you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people from Judah, their infants, wives, and children were standing in front of Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Ruach Yahweh came to Jahaziel. (He was the son of Zechariah, grandson of Benaiah, great-grandson of Jeiel, whose father was Mattaniah, a Levite descended from Asaph.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jahaziel said, “Pay attention to me, everyone from Judah, everyone living in Jerusalem, and King Jehoshaphat. This is what Yahweh says to you: Don’t be frightened or terrified by this large crowd. The battle isn’t yours. It’s Elohim’s.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Tomorrow go into battle against them. They will be coming up the Ziz Pass. You will find them at the end of the valley in front of the Jeruel Desert.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You won’t fight this battle. Instead, take your position, stand still, and see the victory of Yahweh for you, Judah and Jerusalem. Don’t be frightened or terrified. Tomorrow go out to face them. Yahweh is with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat bowed down with his face touching the ground. Everyone from Judah and the people who lived in Jerusalem immediately bowed down in front of Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levites, descendants of Kohath and Korah, stood up to praise Yahweh Elohim of Israel with very loud songs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They got up early in the morning and went to the desert of Tekoa. As they were leaving, Jehoshaphat stopped and said, “Listen to me, people of Judah and those living in Jerusalem. Trust Yahweh your Elohim, and believe. Believe his prophets, and you will succeed.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he had advised the people, he appointed people to sing to Yahweh and praise him for the beauty of his holiness. As they went in front of the troops, they sang, “Thank Yahweh because his mercy endures forever!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As they started to sing praises, Yahweh set ambushes against the Ammonites, Moabites, and the people of Mount Seir who had come into Judah. They were defeated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Ammonites and Moabites attacked the people from Mount Seir and annihilated them. After they had finished off the people of Seir, they helped destroy one another.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Judah went to the watchtower in the desert and looked for the crowd. Corpses were lying on the ground. No one had escaped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jehoshaphat and his troops came to take the loot, they found among them a lot of goods, clothes, and valuables. They found more than they could carry. They spent three days collecting the loot.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: On the fourth day they gathered in the valley of Beracah. Because they thanked Yahweh there, that place is still called the valley of Beracah [Thanks] today.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the men of Judah and Jerusalem returned to Jerusalem. They rejoiced while Jehoshaphat led them. Yahweh gave them a reason to rejoice about what had happened to their enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they brought harps, lyres, and trumpets to Yahweh’s temple in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The fear of Elohim came over the kingdoms in that area when they heard how Yahweh waged war against Israel’s enemies.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat’s kingdom was peaceful, since his Elohim surrounded him with peace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat ruled as king of Judah. He was 35 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for 25 years in Jerusalem. His mother’s name was Azubah, daughter of Shilhi.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat carefully followed the example his father Asa had set and did what Yahweh considered right.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the illegal worship sites on the hills were not torn down. The people still didn’t have their hearts set on the Elohim of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything else about Jehoshaphat from first to last is written in the records of Jehu, son of Hanani, which is included in the Book of the Kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, King Jehoshaphat of Judah allied himself with King Ahaziah of Israel, who led him to do evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat joined him in making ships to go to Tarshish. They made the ships in Ezion Geber.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Eliezer, son of Dodavahu from Mareshah, prophesied against Jehoshaphat. He said, “Yahweh will destroy your work because you have allied yourself with Ahaziah.” So the ships were wrecked and couldn’t go to Tarshish.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoshaphat lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried with them in the City of David. His son Jehoram succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had the following brothers, sons of Jehoshaphat: Azariah, Jehiel, Zechariah, Azariahu, Michael, and Shephatiah. All were the sons of King Jehoshaphat of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Their father gave them many gifts: silver, gold, and other expensive things, along with fortified cities in Judah. But Jehoshaphat gave the kingdom to Jehoram, who was the firstborn.
verses.speaker: Narrator
