verses.text: After Jehoram had taken over his father’s kingdom, he strengthened his position and then executed all his brothers and some of the officials of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoram was 32 years old when he became king, and he ruled for 8 years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed the ways of the kings of Israel, as Ahab’s family had done, because his wife was Ahab’s daughter. So he did what Yahweh considered evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Yahweh, recalling the promise he had made to David, didn’t want to destroy David’s family. Yahweh had told David that he would always give him and his descendants a shining lamp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: During Jehoram’s time Edom rebelled against Judah and chose its own king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoram took all his chariot commanders to attack. The Edomites and their chariot commanders surrounded him, but he got up at night and broke through their lines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Edom rebelled against Judah’s rule and is still independent today. At the same time Edom rebelled, Libnah rebelled because Jehoram had abandoned Yahweh Elohim of his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoram made illegal places of worship in the hills of Judah. This caused the inhabitants of Jerusalem to chase after foreign gods as if they were prostitutes. So he led Judah astray.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then a letter came to him from the prophet Elijah. It read, “This is what Yahweh Elohim of your ancestor David says: You haven’t followed the ways of your father Jehoshaphat or the ways of King Asa of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Instead, you have followed the ways of the kings of Israel. You, like Ahab’s family, have caused Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem to chase after foreign gods as if they were prostitutes. You have killed your brothers, your father’s family. Your brothers were better than you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh will strike a great blow to your people, your sons, your wives, and all your property because you did this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You will suffer from a chronic intestinal disease until your intestines come out.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh prompted the Philistines and the Arabs who lived near the people of Sudan to attack Jehoram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They fought against Judah, broke into the country, and took away everything that could be found in the royal palace. They even took Jehoram’s sons and wives. The only son left was Ahaziah, Jehoram’s youngest son.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Yahweh struck Jehoram with an incurable intestinal disease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Two years later, as his life was coming to an end, his intestines fell out because of his sickness. He died a painful death.
His people did not make a bonfire in his honor as they had done for his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was 32 years old when he became king, and he ruled for 8 years in Jerusalem. No one was sorry to see him die. He was buried in the City of David but not in the tombs of the kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Jerusalem made Jehoram’s youngest son Ahaziah king in his place, because the raiders who came to the camp with the Arabs had killed all the older sons. So Jehoram’s son Ahaziah became king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaziah was 42 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for one year in Jerusalem. His mother was Athaliah, the granddaughter of Omri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaziah also followed the ways of Ahab’s family, because his mother gave him advice that led him to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what Yahweh considered evil, as Ahab’s family had done. After his father died, they advised him to do what Ahab’s family had done. They did this to destroy him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaziah followed their advice and went with Ahab’s son King Joram of Israel to fight against King Hazael of Aram at Ramoth Gilead. There the Arameans wounded Joram.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joram returned to Jezreel to let his wounds heal. (He had been wounded by the Arameans at Ramah when he fought against King Hazael of Aram.) Then Jehoram’s son Ahaziah went to Jezreel to see Ahab’s son Joram, who was sick.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elohim brought about Ahaziah’s downfall when he went to Joram. He went with Joram to meet Jehu, grandson of Nimshi. (Yahweh had anointed Jehu to destroy Ahab’s family.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jehu was executing judgment on Ahab’s family, he found Judah’s leaders (Ahaziah’s nephews) who were serving Ahaziah, and he killed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He searched for Ahaziah, and Jehu’s men captured him while he was hiding in Samaria. They brought him to Jehu and killed him. Then they buried him. They explained, “Ahaziah is Jehoshaphat’s grandson. Jehoshaphat dedicated his life to serving Yahweh with all his heart.” But no one in Ahaziah’s family was able to rule as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Ahaziah’s mother, Athaliah, saw that her son was dead, she began to destroy the entire royal family of the house of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Jehoshebath, daughter of the king and sister of Ahaziah, took Ahaziah’s son Joash. She saved him from being killed with the king’s other sons, and she put him and his nurse in a bedroom. Jehoshebath was the daughter of King Jehoram and wife of Jehoiada the priest. Because she was also Ahaziah’s sister, she hid Joash from Athaliah. So he wasn’t killed.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash was with the priests. He was hidden in Elohim’s temple for six years while Athaliah ruled the country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the seventh year of Athaliah’s reign, Jehoiada strengthened his position by making an agreement with the company commanders: Azariah, son of Jeroham, Ishmael, son of Jehohanan, Azariah, son of Obed, Maaseiah, son of Adaiah, and Elishaphat, son of Zichri.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They went around Judah, gathered the Levites from all the cities of Judah and the leaders of the families of Israel, and came to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
The whole assembly made an agreement with the king in Elohim’s temple.
Then Jehoiada said to them, “Here is the king’s son. He should be king, as Yahweh said about David’s descendants.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what you must do: One third of you, the priests and Levites who are on duty on the day of worship, must guard the gates.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Another third must be at the royal palace. And another third must be at Foundation Gate. All the people must be in the courtyards of Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: No one should come into Yahweh’s temple except the priests and the Levites who are on duty with them. They may enter because they are holy, but all other people should follow Yahweh’s regulations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levites should surround the king. Each man should have his weapon in his hand. Kill anyone who tries to come into the temple. Stay with the king wherever he goes.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Levites and all the Judeans did what the priest Jehoiada had ordered them. Each took his men who were coming on duty on the day of worship as well as those who were about to go off duty. Jehoiada had not dismissed the priestly divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada gave the commanders the spears and the small and large shields that had belonged to King David but were now in Elohim’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the troops stood with their weapons drawn. They were stationed around the king and around the altar and the temple (from the south side to the north side of the temple).
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they brought out the king’s son, gave him the crown and the religious instructions, and Jehoiada and his sons made him king by anointing him. They said, “Long live the king!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Athaliah heard the people running and praising the king, she went into Yahweh’s temple, where the people were.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She looked, and the king was standing by the pillar at the entrance. The commanders and the trumpeters were by his side. All the people of the land were rejoicing and blowing trumpets. The singers were leading the celebration with songs accompanied by musical instruments. As Athaliah tore her clothes in distress, she said, “Treason, treason!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the priest Jehoiada brought the company commanders who were in charge of the army out of the temple. He said to them, “Take her out of the temple. Use your sword to kill anyone who follows her.” (The priest had said, “Don’t kill her in Yahweh’s temple.”)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they arrested her as she entered Horse Gate of the royal palace, and they killed her there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada made a promise to the Lord on behalf of the king and his people that they would be Yahweh’s people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then all the people went to the temple of Baal and tore it down. They smashed Baal’s altars and his statues and killed Mattan, the priest of Baal, in front of the altars.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Next, Jehoiada appointed officials to be in charge of Yahweh’s temple under the direction of the priests and Levites. (David had arranged them in divisions for Yahweh’s temple. They were appointed to sacrifice burnt offerings to Yahweh as it is written in Moses’ Teachings. They made these offerings with joy and singing as David had directed.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada appointed gatekeepers for the gates of Yahweh’s temple so that no one who was unclean for any reason could enter.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took the company commanders, the nobles, the people’s governors, and all the people of the land, and they brought the king from Yahweh’s temple. They went through Upper Gate to the royal palace and seated the king on the royal throne. The nobles, the governors of the people, and
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: all the people of the land were celebrating. But the city was quiet because they had killed Athaliah with a sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash was 7 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for 40 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Zibiah from Beersheba.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash did what Yahweh considered right, as long as the priest Jehoiada lived.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiada got Joash two wives, and Joash had sons and daughters.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Joash wanted to renovate Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He gathered the priests and the Levites and said to them, “Go to the cities of Judah, and collect money throughout Israel to repair the temple of your Elohim every year. Do it immediately!” But the Levites didn’t do it immediately.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the king called for the chief priest Jehoiada and asked him, “Why didn’t you require the Levites to bring the contributions from Judah and Jerusalem? Yahweh’s servant Moses and the assembly had required Israel to give contributions for the use of the tent containing the words of God’s promise.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (The sons of that wicked woman Athaliah had broken into Elohim’s temple and used all the holy things of Yahweh’s temple to worship other gods—the Baals.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king issued an order, and they made a box and placed it outside the gate of Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they issued a proclamation in Judah and Jerusalem that the contributions should be brought to Yahweh. (In the desert Elohim’s servant Moses had required Israel to make contributions.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officials and all the people were overjoyed. They brought the money and dropped it into the box until it was full.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Whenever the Levites brought the box to the king’s officers and they saw a lot of money, the king’s scribe and the chief priest’s officer would empty the box and put it back in its place. They would do this every day, so they collected a lot of money.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and Jehoiada would give the money to the foremen who were working on Yahweh’s temple, and they hired masons and carpenters to renovate Yahweh’s temple. They also hired men who worked with iron and bronze to repair Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As the men worked, the project progressed under the foremen’s guidance. They restored Elohim’s temple to its proper condition and reinforced it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they finished, they brought the rest of the money to the king and Jehoiada, who used it to make utensils for Yahweh’s temple. They made dishes and gold and silver utensils for the service and for the offerings. As long as Jehoiada lived, they sacrificed burnt offerings in Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Jehoiada was old and had lived out his years, he died. He was 130 years old when he died.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was buried in the City of David with the kings because of the good he had done in Israel for Elohim and the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After he died, the officials of Judah bowed in front of the king with their faces touching the ground. Then the king listened to their advice.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They abandoned the temple of Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors and worshiped idols and the poles dedicated to the goddess Asherah. This offense of theirs brought Elohim’s anger upon Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh sent them prophets to bring them back to himself. The prophets warned them, but they wouldn’t listen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ruach Elohim gave Zechariah, son of the priest Jehoiada, strength. Zechariah stood in front of the people and said to them, “This is what Elohim says: Why are you breaking Yahweh’s commands? You won’t prosper that way! Yahweh has abandoned you because you have abandoned him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they plotted against Zechariah, and by the king’s order they stoned him to death in the courtyard of Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Joash did not remember how kind Zechariah’s father, Jehoiada, had been to him. Instead, he killed Jehoiada’s son. As Zechariah died, he said, “May Yahweh see this and get revenge!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At the end of the year, the Aramean army attacked Joash. They came to Judah and Jerusalem and destroyed all the people’s leaders. The Arameans sent all the loot they took from Judah and Jerusalem to the king of Damascus.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Aramean army had come with a small number of men, but Yahweh handed Joash’s large army over to them because Joash’s soldiers had abandoned Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors. So the Arameans carried out the Lord’s judgment on Joash.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the Arameans withdrew, they left him suffering from many wounds. His own officials plotted against him for murdering the son of the priest Jehoiada. They killed Joash in his bed. When he died, they buried him in the City of David, but they didn’t bury him in the tombs of the kings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These were the men who conspired against him: Zabad, son of an Ammonite woman named Shimeath, and Jehozabad, son of a Moabite woman named Shimrith.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The record about his sons, the many divine revelations against him, and the rebuilding of Elohim’s temple is in the notes made in the Book of the Kings. His son Amaziah succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah was 25 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for 29 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Jehoaddan from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what Yahweh considered right, but he did not do it wholeheartedly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as he had firm control over the kingdom, he executed the officials who killed his father, the former king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But he didn’t execute their children. He obeyed Yahweh’s command written in the Book of Moses’ Teachings: “Parents must never be put to death for the crimes of their children, and children must never be put to death for the crimes of their parents. Each person must be put to death for his own crime.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah called the people of Judah together and assigned them by families to regiment and battalion commanders for all of Judah and Benjamin. He organized those who were at least 20 years old and found that he had 300,000 of the best men for the army, those who could handle a spear and a shield.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also hired 100,000 soldiers from Israel for 7,500 pounds of silver.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But a man of Elohim came to him and said, “Your Majesty, Israel’s army must not go with you, because Yahweh isn’t with Israel. He’s not with these men from Ephraim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: If you go into battle with them, no matter how courageous you are, Elohim will use the enemy to defeat you, because Elohim has the power to help you or to defeat you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Amaziah asked the man of Elohim, “What should I do about the 7,500 pounds of silver I gave the troops from Israel?”
The man of Elohim answered, “Yahweh can give you much more than that.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Amaziah dismissed the troops that had come to him from Ephraim. But they became furious with Judah and returned home.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amaziah courageously led his troops. When he came to the Dead Sea region, he killed 10,000 men from Seir.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Judeans captured another 10,000 alive, took them to the top of a cliff, and threw them off the top of the cliff so that they were dismembered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The troops that Amaziah sent back so that they couldn’t go with him into battle raided the towns in Judah from Samaria to Beth Horon. They killed 3,000 people and took a lot of goods.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Amaziah came back from defeating the Edomites, he brought the gods of the people of Seir, set them up as his gods, bowed down to them, and burned sacrifices to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh became angry with Amaziah. He sent him a prophet who asked him, “Why do you dedicate your life to serving the gods of those people? Those gods couldn’t save their own people from you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
As he was talking, the king asked him, “Did we make you an adviser to the king? Stop! Do you want me to have you killed?”
The prophet stopped. He said, “I know that Elohim has decided to destroy you because you did this, but you refuse to listen to my advice.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After getting advice from his advisers, King Amaziah of Judah sent messengers to King Jehoash, son of Jehoahaz and grandson of Jehu of Israel, to declare war on Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Jehoash of Israel sent this message to King Amaziah of Judah: “A thistle in Lebanon sent a message to a cedar in Lebanon. It said, ‘Let your daughter marry my son,’ but a wild animal from Lebanon came along and trampled the thistle.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You say you defeated Edom, and now you’ve become arrogant enough to look for more fame. Stay home! Why must you invite disaster and your own defeat and take Judah with you?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Amaziah wouldn’t listen. (Elohim made this happen because he wanted to hand over the Judeans to Jehoash because they had sought help from Edom’s gods.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So King Jehoash of Israel attacked, and King Amaziah of Judah met him in battle at Beth Shemesh in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Israel defeated the army of Judah, and the Judeans fled to their homes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Jehoash of Israel captured King Amaziah, son of Joash and grandson of Ahaziah of Judah, at Beth Shemesh and brought him to Jerusalem. He tore down a 600-foot section of the wall around Jerusalem from Ephraim Gate to Corner Gate.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He took all the gold, silver, and all the utensils he found in Elohim’s temple with Obed Edom and in the royal palace treasury. He also took hostages. Then he returned to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Joash’s son King Amaziah of Judah lived 15 years after the death of Jehoahaz’s son King Jehoash of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t everything else about Amaziah, from beginning to end, written in the Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After Amaziah turned away from Yahweh, conspirators in Jerusalem plotted against him. Amaziah fled to Lachish, but they sent men to Lachish after him and killed him there.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought him back by horse and buried him in the city of Judah with his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the people of Judah took Uzziah, who was 16 years old, and made him king in place of his father Amaziah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah rebuilt Elath and returned it to Judah after King Amaziah lay down in death with his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah was 16 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for 52 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Jecoliah from Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what Yahweh considered right, as his father Amaziah had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He dedicated his life to serving Elohim in the days of Zechariah, who taught him to fear Elohim. As long as he dedicated his life to serving Yahweh, Elohim gave him success.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah went to wage war against the Philistines. He tore down the walls of Gath, Jabneh, and Ashdod. He built cities near Ashdod and elsewhere among the Philistines.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Elohim helped him when he attacked the Philistines, the Arabs who lived in Gur Baal, and the Meunites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Ammonites paid taxes to Uzziah, and his fame spread to the border of Egypt because he became very powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah built towers in Jerusalem at Corner Wall, Valley Gate, and the Angle, and he reinforced them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built towers in the desert. He dug many cisterns because he had a lot of herds in the foothills and the plains. He had farmers and vineyard workers in the mountains and the fertile fields because he loved the soil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah had an army of professional soldiers. They were ready to go to war in their companies based on the number organized by the scribe Jeiel and the officer Maaseiah. They were commanded by Hananiah, one of the king’s officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The total number of family heads among these warriors was 2,600.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Under them was an army of 307,500 soldiers. They were a powerful force that could support the king against the enemy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: For the entire army Uzziah prepared shields, spears, helmets, armor, bows, and stones for slings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
In Jerusalem he made machines designed by inventive people. The machines were placed on the towers and corners to shoot arrows and hurl large stones.
Uzziah’s fame spread far and wide because he had strong support until he became powerful.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But when he became powerful, his pride destroyed him. He was unfaithful to Yahweh his Elohim. He went into Yahweh’s temple to burn incense on the incense altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priest Azariah went in after him with 80 of Yahweh’s courageous priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They opposed King Uzziah. They said to him, “Uzziah, you have no right to burn incense as an offering to Yahweh. That right belongs to the priests, Aaron’s descendants, who have been given the holy task of burning incense. Get out of the holy place because you have been unfaithful. Yahweh Elohim will not honor you for this.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah, who held an incense burner in his hand, became angry. While he was angry with the priests, a skin disease broke out on his forehead. This happened in front of the priests in Yahweh’s temple as Uzziah was at the incense altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the chief priest Azariah and all the priests turned toward him, a skin disease was on his forehead. They rushed him away. Uzziah was in a hurry to get out because Yahweh had inflicted him with the disease.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Uzziah had a skin disease until the day he died. Since he had a skin disease, he lived in a separate house and was barred from Yahweh’s temple. His son Jotham was in charge of the royal palace and governed the country.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything else about Uzziah, from beginning to end, is recorded by the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Uzziah lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried with them in a field containing tombs that belonged to the kings. People said, “He had a skin disease.” His son Jotham succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham was 25 years old when he began to rule. He ruled for 16 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Jerushah, daughter of Zadok.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what Yahweh considered right, as his father Uzziah had done. But unlike his father, he didn’t illegally enter Yahweh’s temple. Nevertheless, the people continued their corrupt ways.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham built the Upper Gate of Yahweh’s temple and did extensive building of the wall at the Ophel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built cities in the hills of Judah, and he built forts and towers in the wooded areas.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He fought with the king of the Ammonites and conquered them. That year the Ammonites gave him 7,500 pounds of silver, 60,000 bushels of wheat, and 60,000 bushels of barley. The Ammonites gave him the same amount for two more years.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham grew powerful because he was determined to live as Yahweh his Elohim wanted.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything else about Jotham—all his wars and his life—is written in the Book of the Kings of Israel and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He was 25 years old when he began to rule as king. He ruled for 16 years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jotham lay down in death with his ancestors, and they buried him in the City of David. His son Ahaz succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz was 20 years old when he began to rule. He ruled for 26 years in Jerusalem. He didn’t do what Yahweh considered right, as his ancestor David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He followed the example of the kings of Israel and even made metal idols for worshiping other gods—the Baals.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He burned sacrifices in the valley of Ben Hinnom and sacrificed his son by burning him alive, one of the disgusting things done by the nations that Yahweh had forced out of the Israelites’ way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He offered sacrifices and burned incense as an offering at the illegal worship sites, which were on hills and under every large tree.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Yahweh his Elohim handed him over to the king of Aram, who defeated him, captured many prisoners, and brought them to Damascus. He also handed him over to the king of Israel, who decisively defeated him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In one day Pekah, son of Remaliah, killed 120,000 soldiers in Judah because they had abandoned Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zichri, a fighting man from Ephraim, killed Maaseiah, who was the king’s son, Azrikam, who was in charge of the palace, and Elkanah, who was the king’s second-in-command.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites captured 200,000 women, boys, and girls from their relatives the Judeans. They also took a lot of goods from Judah and brought them to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A prophet of Yahweh named Oded was there. He went to meet the army coming home to Samaria. He said to them, “Yahweh Elohim of your ancestors handed Judah over to you in his anger. You killed them in a rage that reaches up to heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now you intend to enslave the men and women of Judah and Jerusalem. But aren’t you also guilty of sinning against Yahweh your Elohim?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Listen to me. Return these prisoners you have captured from your relatives, because Yahweh is very angry with you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Azariah, son of Jehohan, Berechiah, son of Meshillemoth, Jehizkiah, son of Shallum, and Amasa, son of Hadlai (some leaders of Ephraim) opposed those coming home from the army.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They said to the army, “Don’t bring the prisoners here. You’ll make us responsible for this sin against Yahweh. Do you intend to add to all our sins? Yahweh is very angry with Israel because we have already sinned.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the army left the prisoners and the loot in front of the leaders and the whole assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the men who were mentioned by name took charge of the prisoners and gave clothes from the loot to all the prisoners who were naked. They provided clothes for them, gave them sandals, gave them something to eat and drink, and let them bathe. They put everyone who was exhausted on donkeys and brought them to Jericho (the City of Palms) near their own people. Then they returned to Samaria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: At that time King Ahaz sent for help from the kings of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Edomites had again invaded and defeated Judah and captured prisoners.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Philistines had raided the foothills and the Negev in Judah. They captured and began living in Beth Shemesh, Aijalon, Gederoth, Soco and its villages, Timnah and its villages, and Gimzo and its villages.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh humbled Judah because of King Ahaz of Israel. Ahaz had spread sin throughout Judah and was unfaithful to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Tillegath Pilneser of Assyria attacked Ahaz. Instead of strengthening Ahaz, Tillegath Pilneser made trouble for him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz took some of the things from Yahweh’s temple, the royal palace, and the princes, and he gave them to the king of Assyria. But that didn’t help him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he had this trouble, King Ahaz became more unfaithful to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He sacrificed to the gods of Damascus, the gods who had defeated him. He thought, “The gods of the kings of Aram are helping them. I’ll sacrifice to them so that they will help me.” But they ruined him and all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz collected the utensils in Elohim’s temple, cut them up, and closed the doors to Yahweh’s temple. He made altars for himself on every corner in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: And in each city of Judah, he made places of worship to sacrifice to other gods. So he made Yahweh Elohim of his ancestors angry.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything else about him—everything from beginning to end—is written in the Book of the Kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Ahaz lay down in death with his ancestors and was buried in the city of Jerusalem because they didn’t put him into the tombs of the kings of Israel. His son Hezekiah succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah began to rule as king when he was 25 years old. He ruled for 29 years in Jerusalem. His mother was Abijah, daughter of Zechariah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what Yahweh considered right, as his ancestor David had done.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the first month of his first year as king, he opened the doors of Yahweh’s temple and repaired them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought the priests and Levites together in the square on the east side of the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He said to them, “Listen to me, Levites. Perform the ceremonies to make the temple of Yahweh Elohim of your ancestors holy. Remove anything that has been corrupted from the holy place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our ancestors were unfaithful and did what Yahweh our Elohim considered evil. They deserted him. They turned away from Yahweh’s tent and turned their backs on him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They also shut the doors of the temple’s entrance hall, extinguished the lamps, and didn’t burn incense or sacrifice burnt offerings in the holy place to the Elohim of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Yahweh was angry with Judah and Jerusalem. He made them something that shocks and terrifies people and that people ridicule, as you can see with your own eyes.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Our fathers were killed in battle, and our sons, daughters, and wives are prisoners because of this.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Now I intend to make a pledge to Yahweh Elohim of Israel so that he may turn his burning anger away from us.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t be negligent, my sons. Yahweh has chosen you to stand in front of him, serve him, be his servants, and burn sacrifices.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
So the Levites started to work.
From Kohath’s descendants were Mahath, son of Amasai, and Joel, son of Azariah.
From Merari’s descendants were Kish, son of Abdi, and Azariah, son of Jehallelel.
From Gershon’s descendants were Joah, son of Zimmah, and Eden, son of Joah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From Elizaphan’s descendants were Shimri and Jeiel.
From Asaph’s descendants were Zechariah and Mattaniah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
From Heman’s descendants were Jehiel and Shimei.
From Jeduthun’s descendants were Shemaiah and Uzziel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: These men gathered their relatives and performed the ceremonies to make themselves holy. Then they obeyed the king’s order from Yahweh’s word and entered the temple to make it clean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests entered Yahweh’s temple to make it clean. They carried into the courtyard every unclean thing that they found in Yahweh’s temple. Then the Levites took the unclean items outside the city to the Kidron Brook.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They started on the first day of the first month. On the eighth day they went into Yahweh’s entrance hall, and for eight days they performed the ceremonies to make Yahweh’s temple holy. They finished on the sixteenth day of the first month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they went to King Hezekiah. They said to him, “We have made all of Yahweh’s temple clean. This includes the altar for burnt offerings, all its utensils, the table for the rows of bread and all its utensils,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and all the utensils King Ahaz refused to use during his reign when he was unfaithful. We have restored them and made them holy. They are in front of Yahweh’s altar.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Early in the morning Hezekiah gathered the leaders of the city and went to Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They brought seven bulls, seven rams, seven lambs, and seven male goats as an offering for sin for the kingdom, the holy place, and Judah. Hezekiah told the priests, Aaron’s descendants, to sacrifice the animals on Yahweh’s altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they slaughtered the bulls, and the priests sprinkled the blood on the altar. Then they slaughtered the rams and sprinkled the blood on the altar. After that, they slaughtered the lambs and sprinkled the blood on the altar.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then they brought the male goats for the offering for sin in front of the king and the assembly, who laid their hands on them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests slaughtered the goats and made their blood an offering for sin at the altar to make peace with the Lord for Israel. The king had said that the burnt offerings and offerings for sin should be for all Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had the Levites stand in Yahweh’s temple with cymbals, harps, and lyres as David, the king’s seer Gad, and the prophet Nathan had ordered. This command came from Yahweh through his prophets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Levites stood with David’s instruments, and the priests had the trumpets.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hezekiah ordered the sacrificing of burnt offerings on the altar. When the burnt offerings started, the songs to Yahweh started. These songs were accompanied by trumpets and the instruments of King David of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole assembly bowed down with their faces touching the ground, singers began to sing, and the trumpets blew until the burnt offering was finished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the burnt offerings were finished, the king and everyone who was with him kneeled and bowed down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Hezekiah and the leaders told the Levites to praise Yahweh with the words of David and the seer Asaph. They joyfully sang praises, bowed down, and worshiped.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Hezekiah said, “You have dedicated your lives to Yahweh. Come, bring sacrifices and thank offerings to Yahweh’s temple.”
The assembly brought sacrifices and thank offerings, and everyone who was willing brought burnt offerings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The burnt offerings brought by the assembly totaled 70 bulls, 100 rams, and 200 lambs. All of these were burnt offerings to Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The animals dedicated as holy sacrifices were 600 bulls and 3,000 sheep.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But the priests needed more help to skin all the burnt offerings. So their relatives, the Levites, helped them until the work was completed and the priests could make themselves holy. The Levites were more diligent in making themselves holy than the priests were.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: There were many burnt offerings in addition to the fat of the fellowship offerings and wine offerings that accompanied the burnt offerings. So the worship in Yahweh’s temple was reestablished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah and all the people were overjoyed because of what Elohim had done for the people. Everything had happened so quickly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah sent a message to all Israel and Judah and wrote letters to the tribes of Ephraim and Manasseh. He invited them to come to Yahweh’s temple in Jerusalem to celebrate the Passover of Yahweh Elohim of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king, his officials, and the whole assembly in Jerusalem decided to celebrate the Passover in the second month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They couldn’t celebrate it at the regular time because not enough priests had performed the ceremonies to make themselves holy and the people hadn’t gathered in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king and the whole assembly considered their plan to be the right thing to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So they decided to send an announcement throughout Israel from Beersheba to Dan. They summoned everyone to come to Jerusalem to celebrate the Passover of Yahweh Elohim of Israel. These people had not celebrated it in large numbers as the written instructions said they should.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Messengers took letters from the king and his officials throughout Israel and Judah. The king’s order said, “Israelites, return to Yahweh Elohim of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel. Then he will return to the few of you who escaped from the power of the kings of Assyria.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t be like your ancestors and your relatives who were unfaithful to Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors. He made them something that shocks people, as you have seen.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t be impossible to deal with like your ancestors. Reach out for Yahweh. Come to his holy place that he made holy forever. Serve Yahweh your Elohim, and he will turn his burning anger away from you.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When you return to Yahweh, your relatives and children will find compassion from those who captured them. They will return to this land. Yahweh your Elohim is merciful and compassionate. He will not turn his face away from you if you return to him.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the messengers went from city to city in the territories of Ephraim and Manasseh, as far as Zebulun. But the people ridiculed them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: However, some people from Asher, Manasseh, and Zebulun humbled themselves and came to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Also, Elohim guided the people of Judah so that they united to carry out the command which the king and the leaders gave from Yahweh’s word.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many people gathered in Jerusalem to celebrate the Festival of Unleavened Bread in the second month. They formed a large assembly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people got rid of the idols’ altars in Jerusalem. They got rid of all the altars for incense by dumping them in the Kidron Valley.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They slaughtered the Passover lamb on the fourteenth day of the second month. The priests and Levites were ashamed, so they performed the ceremonies to make themselves holy. Then they brought burnt offerings to Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They stood in their regular places as instructed by Moses’ Teachings. (Moses was a man of Elohim.) The priests sprinkled the blood they received from the Levites.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many people in the assembly had not made themselves holy. So the Levites had to kill the Passover lambs for all who weren’t clean and couldn’t make their lambs holy for Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many people from Ephraim, Manasseh, Issachar, and Zebulun had not made themselves clean. So they ate the Passover, but not in the way the written instructions said they should. Hezekiah prayed for them: “May the good Yahweh forgive
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: those who have their hearts set on dedicating their lives to serving Elohim. May Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors do this for those who are not clean as required for the holy place.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh listened to Hezekiah and healed the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the Israelites in Jerusalem celebrated the Festival of Unleavened Bread for seven days with great joy. Each day the Levites and priests praised Yahweh in song. They played Yahweh’s instruments loudly.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah spoke encouraging words to all the Levites who had the skills to serve Yahweh. They ate the festival meals for seven days, sacrificed fellowship offerings, and confessed their sins to Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the whole assembly decided to celebrate the festival for seven more days. So they joyfully celebrated for seven more days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hezekiah of Judah provided 1,000 bulls and 7,000 sheep as sacrifices for the assembly. The leaders provided 1,000 bulls and 10,000 sheep for the assembly. So a large number of priests were able to perform the ceremonies to make themselves holy.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The whole assembly from Judah, the priests, the Levites, the whole assembly from Israel, the foreigners who came from Israel, and those who lived in Judah rejoiced.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The city of Jerusalem was filled with joy. Nothing like this had happened in Jerusalem since the days of King Solomon of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the Levitical priests blessed the people. Their voices were heard, and their prayers went to Elohim’s holy place in heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When this was over, all the Israelites who were there went to the cities in Judah. They crushed the sacred stones, cut down the poles dedicated to the goddess Asherah, and tore down the illegal places of worship and the altars throughout Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh. The Israelites destroyed all of these things. Then all the Israelites returned to their own cities. Each person went to his own property.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah assigned the priests and the Levites to divisions. Each priest or Levite was put in a division based on the service he performed: sacrificing burnt offerings, sacrificing fellowship offerings, serving, giving thanks, or praising within the gates of Yahweh’s camp.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He set aside part of the king’s property for burnt offerings, the morning and evening offerings, burnt offerings on the weekly worship days, the New Moon Festivals, and the annual festivals, as it is written in Yahweh’s Teachings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told the people living in Jerusalem to give the priests and Levites the portions they were due so that they could devote themselves to Yahweh’s Teachings.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: As soon as the word spread, the Israelites brought plenty of offerings from the first of their produce: grain, new wine, fresh olive oil, honey, and every crop from the fields. They brought large quantities, a tenth of everything.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people of Israel and Judah who were living in the cities of Judah brought a tenth of their cattle and sheep and a tenth of the holy things they had dedicated to Yahweh their Elohim. They piled these holy things in heaps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the third month they started piling them up, and in the seventh month they finished.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hezekiah and the leaders saw the heaps, they praised Yahweh and his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah asked the priests and the Levites about the heaps.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The chief priest Azariah from Zadok’s family said, “Since the people started to bring the offerings to Yahweh’s temple, we have had all we wanted to eat and plenty to spare. Yahweh has blessed his people, and there’s a lot left over.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then Hezekiah told them to prepare storerooms in Yahweh’s temple. After they had prepared them,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: they faithfully brought in the contributions, the offerings of one-tenth of the crops, and the gifts dedicated to God. The Levite Conaniah was in charge of these things, and his brother Shimei was his assistant.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Hezekiah and Azariah, who was in charge of Elohim’s temple, appointed Jehiel, Azaziah, Nahath, Asahel, Jerimoth, Jozabad, Eliel, Ismachiah, Mahath, and Benaiah to serve under Conaniah and his brother Shimei.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Kore, son of Imnah the Levite, was the gatekeeper at East Gate and had to take care of the freewill offerings made to Elohim. His responsibility was to distribute the offerings made to Yahweh and the holy gifts dedicated to God.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Eden, Miniamin, Jeshua, Shemaiah, Amariah, and Shecaniah served under him in the cities belonging to the priests. They were to distribute the offerings faithfully to all their relatives, young and old, by their divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were appointed to distribute them to males who were at least three years old. The way they were enrolled in the genealogical records did not matter. The six men who served under Kore were to distribute the offerings to everyone who went to Yahweh’s temple to perform the daily service that each division was responsible for.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They were to distribute offerings to the priests who were enrolled by families and to the Levites who were at least 20 years old. Distribution was based on the way they served in their divisions.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The priests and Levites were enrolled with their wives, sons, daughters, and other people who depended on them—the whole community. The priests and Levites had to be faithful in keeping themselves holy for the holy work.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Men were appointed to give a portion of the offerings to all the males in the priestly families and to everyone listed in the genealogies of the Levites. These men were Aaron’s descendants, priests who lived in the pasturelands of every Levite city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what Hezekiah did throughout Judah. He did what was good and right and true to Yahweh his Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah incorporated Moses’ Teachings and commands into worship and dedicated his life to serving Elohim. Whatever he did for the worship in Elohim’s temple, he did wholeheartedly, and he succeeded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After everything Hezekiah had done so faithfully, King Sennacherib of Assyria came to invade Judah. He set up camp to attack the fortified cities. He intended to conquer them himself.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Hezekiah saw that Sennacherib had come to wage war against Jerusalem,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: he, his officers, and his military staff made plans to stop the water from flowing out of the springs outside the city. They helped him do it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: A large crowd gathered as they stopped all the springs and the brook that flowed through the land. They said, “Why should the kings of Assyria find plenty of water?”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah worked hard. He rebuilt all the broken sections of the wall, made the towers taller, built another wall outside the city wall, strengthened the Millo in the City of David, and made plenty of weapons and shields.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He appointed military commanders over the troops and gathered the commanders in the square by the city gate. He spoke these words of encouragement:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “Be strong and courageous. Don’t be frightened or terrified by the king of Assyria or the crowd with him. Someone greater is on our side.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Assyria has human power on his side, but Yahweh our Elohim is on our side to help us and fight our battles.” So the people were encouraged by what King Hezekiah of Judah said.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, while King Sennacherib of Assyria and all his royal forces were attacking Lachish, he sent his officers to King Hezekiah of Judah and to all of the people in Judah who were in Jerusalem to say:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “This is what King Sennacherib of Assyria says: Why are you so confident as you live in Jerusalem while it is blockaded?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t Hezekiah misleading you and abandoning you to die from hunger and thirst when he says, ‘Yahweh our Elohim will rescue us from the king of Assyria?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Isn’t this the same Hezekiah who got rid of Yahweh’s places of worship and altars and told Judah and Jerusalem, ‘Worship and sacrifice at one altar?’
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t you know what I and my predecessors have done to the people of all other countries? Were any of the gods of these other nations ever able to rescue their countries from me?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Were the gods of these nations able to rescue their people from my control? My predecessors claimed and destroyed those nations. Is your Elohim able to rescue you from my control?
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Don’t let Hezekiah deceive you or persuade you like this. Don’t believe him. No god of any nation or kingdom could save his people from me or my ancestors. Certainly, your Elohim will not rescue you from me!”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sennacherib’s officers said more against Yahweh Elohim and his servant Hezekiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sennacherib wrote letters cursing Yahweh Elohim of Israel. These letters said, “As the gods of the nations in other countries couldn’t rescue their people from me, Hezekiah’s Elohim cannot rescue his people from me.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Sennacherib’s officers shouted loudly in the Judean language to the troops who were on the wall of Jerusalem. They tried to frighten and terrify the troops so that they could capture the city.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They spoke about the Elohim of Jerusalem as if he were one of the gods made by human hands and worshiped by the people in other countries.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then King Hezekiah and the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz, prayed about this and called to heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh sent an angel who exterminated all the soldiers, officials, and commanders in the Assyrian king’s camp. Humiliated, Sennacherib returned to his own country. When he went into the temple of his god, some of his own sons killed him with a sword.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Yahweh saved Hezekiah and the people living in Jerusalem from King Sennacherib of Assyria and from everyone else. Yahweh gave them peace with all their neighbors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Many people still went to Jerusalem to bring gifts to Yahweh and expensive presents to King Hezekiah of Judah. From then on, he was considered important by all the nations.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In those days Hezekiah became sick and was about to die. He prayed to Yahweh, who answered him and gave him a miraculous sign.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Hezekiah was conceited, so he didn’t repay Yahweh for his kindness. Yahweh became angry with him, with Judah, and with Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah and the people living in Jerusalem humbled themselves when they realized they had become conceited. So Yahweh didn’t vent his anger on them during Hezekiah’s time.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah became richer and was highly honored. He prepared storerooms for himself to hold silver, gold, precious stones, spices, shields, and all kinds of valuables.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made sheds to store his harvests of grain, new wine, and fresh olive oil, and he made barns for all his cattle and stalls for his flocks.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He made cities for himself because he had many sheep and cattle. Elohim had given him a lot of property.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah was the one who stopped the water from flowing from the upper outlet of Gihon. He channeled the water directly underground to the west side of the City of David. Hezekiah succeeded in everything he did.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the leaders of Babylon sent ambassadors to ask him about the miraculous sign that had happened in the land, Elohim left him. Elohim did this to test him, to find out everything that was in Hezekiah’s heart.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything else about Hezekiah, including his devotion to Elohim, is written in the vision of the prophet Isaiah, son of Amoz, and in the records of the kings of Judah and Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hezekiah lay down in death with his ancestors. He was buried in the upper tombs of David’s descendants. When Hezekiah died, all of Judah and the people in Jerusalem honored him. His son Manasseh succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh was 12 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for 55 years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what Yahweh considered evil by copying the disgusting things done by the nations that Yahweh had forced out of the Israelites’ way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He rebuilt the illegal places of worship that his father Hezekiah had torn down. He set up altars dedicated to other gods—the Baals—and made a pole dedicated to the goddess Asherah as King Ahab of Israel had done. Manasseh, like Ahab, worshiped and served the entire army of heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built altars in Yahweh’s temple, where Yahweh had said, “My name will be in Jerusalem forever.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the two courtyards of Yahweh’s temple, he built altars for the entire army of heaven.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He burned his son as a sacrifice in the valley of Ben Hinnom, consulted fortunetellers, cast evil spells, practiced witchcraft, and appointed royal mediums and psychics. He did many things that made Yahweh furious.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh had a carved idol made. Then he set it up in Elohim’s temple, where Elohim had said to David and his son Solomon, “I have chosen this temple and Jerusalem from all the tribes of Israel. I will put my name here forever.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will never again remove Israel from the land that I set aside for their ancestors if they will obey all the commands, all the teachings, the ordinances, and the regulations I gave through Moses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh misled Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem so that they did more evil things than the nations that Yahweh had destroyed when the Israelites arrived in the land.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When Yahweh spoke to Manasseh and his people, they wouldn’t even pay attention.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Yahweh made the army commanders of the king of Assyria invade Judah. They took Manasseh captive, put a hook in his nose, put him in bronze shackles, and brought him to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When he experienced this distress, he begged Yahweh his Elohim to be kind and humbled himself in front of the Elohim of his ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He prayed to Yahweh, and Yahweh accepted his prayer and listened to his request. Yahweh brought him back to his kingdom in Jerusalem. Then Manasseh knew that Yahweh is Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After this, Manasseh rebuilt the outer wall of the City of David from west of Gihon Spring in the valley to the entrance of Fish Gate. He made the wall go around the Ophel, and he built it very high. He put army commanders in every fortified city in Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh got rid of the foreign gods and the idol in Yahweh’s temple. He got rid of the altars he had built in the temple on Yahweh’s mountain and in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He built Yahweh’s altar and sacrificed fellowship offerings and thank offerings on it. And he told Judah to serve Yahweh Elohim of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The people continued to sacrifice at the illegal places of worship, but they sacrificed only to Yahweh their Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything else about Manasseh—including his prayer to his Elohim and the words that the seers spoke to him in the name of Yahweh Elohim of Israel—are in the records of the kings of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His prayer and how Elohim accepted it are written in the records of Hozai. The things he did before he humbled himself are also written there. This includes all his sins and unfaithfulness and the places where he built illegal worship sites and set up idols and poles dedicated to the goddess Asherah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Manasseh lay down in death with his ancestors. They buried him in his own palace. His son Amon succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Amon was 22 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for 2 years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what Yahweh considered evil, as his father Manasseh had done. Amon sacrificed to all the idols his father Manasseh had made, and he worshiped them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He didn’t humble himself in front of Yahweh as his father Manasseh had humbled himself. Instead, Amon continued to sin.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His officials plotted against him and killed him in his palace.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the people of the land killed everyone who had plotted against King Amon. They made his son Josiah king in his place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah was 8 years old when he began to rule, and he was king for 31 years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what Yahweh considered right. He lived in the ways of his ancestor David and never stopped living this way.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighth year of his reign, while he was still a boy, he began to dedicate his life to serving the Elohim of his ancestor David. In his twelfth year as king, he began to make Judah and Jerusalem clean by destroying the illegal places of worship, poles dedicated to the goddess Asherah, carved idols, and metal idols.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He had the altars of the various Baal gods torn down. He cut down the incense altars that were above them. He destroyed the Asherah poles, carved idols, and metal idols. He ground them into powder and scattered the powder over the tombs of those who had sacrificed to them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He burned the bones of the priests on their altars. So he made Judah and Jerusalem clean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the cities of Manasseh, Ephraim, Simeon, and as far as Naphtali, he removed all their temples,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: tore down the altars, beat the Asherah poles and idols into powder, and cut down all the incense altars everywhere in Israel. Then he went back to Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighteenth year of his reign as he was making the land and the temple clean, Josiah sent Shaphan, son of Azaliah, Maaseiah, the mayor of the city, and Joah, the royal historian and son of Joahaz, to repair the temple of Yahweh his Elohim.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They came to the chief priest Hilkiah and gave him the money that had been brought to Elohim’s temple, the money that the Levite doorkeepers had collected from the tribes of Manasseh and Ephraim, from all who were left in Israel, from everyone in the tribes of Judah and Benjamin, and from the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They gave the money to the foremen who were in charge of Yahweh’s temple. These foremen gave it to the workmen who were restoring and repairing the temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: (These workers included carpenters and builders.) They were to buy quarried stones and wood for the fittings and beams of the buildings that the kings of Judah had allowed to become run-down.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The men did their work faithfully under the supervision of Jahath and Obadiah (Levites descended from Merari), and Zechariah and Meshullam (descendants of Kohath). The Levites, who were skilled musicians,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: also supervised the workers and directed all the workmen on the various jobs. Some of the Levites served as scribes, officials, or gatekeepers.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When they brought out the money that had been deposited in Yahweh’s temple, the priest Hilkiah found the Book of Yahweh’s Teachings written by Moses.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Hilkiah told the scribe Shaphan, “I have found the Book of the Teachings in Yahweh’s temple.” Hilkiah gave the book to Shaphan.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Shaphan took the book to the king and reported, “We are doing everything you told us to do.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: We took the money that was donated in Yahweh’s temple and gave it to the supervisors and the workmen.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the scribe Shaphan told the king, “The priest Hilkiah has given me a book.” And Shaphan read it to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: When the king heard what the Teachings said, he tore his clothes in distress.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king gave an order to Hilkiah, Ahikam (son of Shaphan), Abdon (son of Micah), the scribe Shaphan, and the royal official Asaiah. He said,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: “On behalf of those who are left in Israel and Judah and me, ask Yahweh about the words in this book that was found. Yahweh’s fierce anger has been poured on us because our ancestors did not obey the word of Yahweh by doing everything written in this book.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So Hilkiah and the king’s officials went to talk to the prophet Huldah about this matter. She was the wife of Shallum, son of Tokhath and grandson of Hasrah. Shallum was in charge of the royal wardrobe. Huldah was living in the Second Part of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: She told them, “This is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says: Tell the man who sent you to me,
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: ‘This is what Yahweh says: I’m going to bring disaster on this place and on the people living here according to the curses written in the book that was read to the king of Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: I will do this because they have abandoned me and sacrificed to other gods in order to make me furious. Therefore, my anger will be poured on this place and will never come to an end.’”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Huldah added, “Tell Judah’s king who sent you to me to ask Yahweh a question, ‘This is what Yahweh Elohim of Israel says about the words you heard:
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: You had a change of heart and humbled yourself in front of Elohim when you heard my words against this place and those who live here. You humbled yourself, tore your clothes in distress, and cried in front of me. So I will listen to you, declares Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
That is why I’m going to bring you to your ancestors. I’m going to bring you to your grave in peace, and your eyes will not see any of the disaster I’m going to bring on this place and those who live here.’”
So they reported this to the king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then the king sent for all the respected leaders of Judah and Jerusalem to join him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king, everyone in Judah, everyone living in Jerusalem, the priests, the Levites, and all the people (young and old) went up to Yahweh’s temple. He read everything written in the Book of the Promise found in Yahweh’s temple so that they could hear it.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king stood in his place and made a promise to Yahweh that he would follow Yahweh and obey his commands, instructions, and laws with all his heart and soul. He said he would live by the terms of the promise written in this book.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He also made all those found in Jerusalem and Benjamin join with him in the promise. Then the people of Jerusalem lived according to the promise of Elohim, the Elohim of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah got rid of all the disgusting idols throughout Israelite territory. He made all people found in Israel serve Yahweh their Elohim. As long as he lived, they didn’t stop following Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah celebrated the Passover for Yahweh in Jerusalem. The Passover lamb was slaughtered on the fourteenth day of the first month.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah appointed the priests to their duties and encouraged them to serve in Yahweh’s temple.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He told the Levites, who instructed all Israel and performed ceremonies to make themselves holy to Yahweh, “Put the holy ark in the temple that Solomon, son of David and king of Israel, built. It shouldn’t be carried on your shoulders any longer. Serve Yahweh your Elohim and his people Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Get yourselves ready with the family groups of your divisions, which are listed in the records of King David of Israel and the records of his son Solomon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Stand in the holy place representing the family divisions of your relatives, the people of Israel. Let the Levites be considered a part of each family.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Slaughter the Passover lamb, perform the ceremonies to make yourselves holy, and prepare the lambs for the other Israelites as Yahweh instructed us through Moses.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Josiah provided the people with 33,000 sheep and goats to be sacrificed as Passover offerings for all who were present. In addition, he provided 3,000 bulls. (These animals were the king’s property.)
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His officials also voluntarily gave animals to the people, priests, and Levites. Hilkiah, Zechariah, and Jehiel, the men in charge of Elohim’s temple, gave the priests 2,600 sheep and goats and 300 bulls for Passover sacrifices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Conaniah and his brothers Shemaiah and Nethanel, and Hashabiah, Jeiel, and Jozabad, the leaders of the Levites, gave the Levites 5,000 sheep and goats and 500 bulls as Passover sacrifices.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So the service was prepared. The priests took their positions with the Levites according to their divisions, as the king had ordered.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They slaughtered the Passover lambs. The priests sprinkled the blood with their hands while the Levites skinned the lambs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They set aside the burnt offerings to give them to the laypeople according to their family divisions. The laypeople could then present them to Yahweh as written in the Book of Moses. The Levites did the same with the bulls.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They roasted the Passover lambs according to the directions. They boiled the holy offerings in pots, kettles, and pans and immediately served them to all the people.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text:
Later, they prepared the animals for themselves and for the priests because the priests (Aaron’s descendants) were sacrificing the burnt offerings and the fat until that evening.
So the Levites prepared the animals for themselves and the priests.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The singers (Asaph’s descendants) were in their places as David, Asaph, Heman, and the king’s seer Jeduthun had commanded. The gatekeepers were stationed at each gate. They didn’t need to leave their work, because their relatives, the Levites, prepared animals for them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So everything was arranged that day for the worship of Yahweh. The Passover was celebrated, and the burnt offerings were sacrificed on Yahweh’s altar as King Josiah had commanded.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The Israelites who were present celebrated the Passover at that time. They also celebrated the Festival of Unleavened Bread for seven days.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Never had a Passover like this been celebrated in Israel during the time of the prophet Samuel or the kings of Israel. They did not celebrate the Passover as Josiah celebrated it with priests, Levites, all of Judah, the people of Israel who could be found, and the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the eighteenth year of Josiah’s reign, this Passover was celebrated.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: After all this, when Josiah had repaired the temple, King Neco of Egypt came to fight a battle at Carchemish at the Euphrates River. Josiah went to attack him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Neco sent messengers to Josiah to say, “What’s your quarrel with me, king of Judah? I’m not attacking you. I’ve come to fight those who are at war with me. Elohim told me to hurry. Elohim is with me, so stop now or else he will destroy you.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But Josiah would not stop his attack. He disguised himself as he went into battle. He refused to listen to Neco’s words, which came from Elohim, and he went to fight in the valley of Megiddo.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Some archers shot King Josiah. The king told his officers, “Take me away because I’m badly wounded.”
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: His officers took him out of the chariot and brought him to Jerusalem in his other chariot. He died and was buried in the tombs of his ancestors. All Judah and Jerusalem mourned for Josiah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jeremiah sang a funeral song about Josiah. All the male and female singers still sing funeral songs about Josiah today. This became a tradition in Israel. They are written in the Book of the Funeral Songs.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything else about Josiah—including his devotion to God by following what is written in Yahweh’s Teachings
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: and his acts from first to last—are written in the records of the kings of Israel and Judah.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Then people of the land took Josiah’s son Jehoahaz and made him king in Jerusalem in place of his father.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoahaz was 23 years old when he became king, and he was king in Jerusalem for 3 months.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Egypt removed him from office in Jerusalem and fined the country 7,500 pounds of silver and 75 pounds of gold.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Egypt made Jehoahaz’s brother Eliakim king of Judah and Jerusalem and changed Eliakim’s name to Jehoiakim. Neco took Jehoahaz away to Egypt.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiakim was 25 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for 11 years in Jerusalem. He did what Yahweh his Elohim considered evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon attacked Jehoiakim and put him in bronze shackles to take him to Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Nebuchadnezzar also brought some of the utensils of Yahweh’s temple to Babylon. He put them in his palace in Babylon.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Everything else about Jehoiakim—the disgusting things he did and all the charges against him—is written in the Book of the Kings of Israel and Judah. His son Jehoiakin succeeded him as king.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Jehoiakin was eight years old when he began to rule as king. He was king for three months and ten days in Jerusalem. He did what Yahweh considered evil.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: In the spring King Nebuchadnezzar sent for Jehoiakin and brought him to Babylon with the valuable utensils from Yahweh’s temple. Nebuchadnezzar made Jehoiakin’s uncle Zedekiah king of Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah was 21 years old when he began to rule, and he ruled for 11 years in Jerusalem.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He did what Yahweh his Elohim considered evil and didn’t humble himself in front of the prophet Jeremiah, who spoke for Yahweh.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Zedekiah also rebelled against King Nebuchadnezzar. Nebuchadnezzar had made Zedekiah swear an oath of allegiance to him in Elohim’s name. But Zedekiah became so stubborn and so impossible to deal with that he refused to turn back to Yahweh Elohim of Israel.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: All the officials, the priests, and the people became increasingly unfaithful and followed all the disgusting practices of the nations. Although Yahweh had made the temple in Jerusalem holy, they made the temple unclean.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: Yahweh Elohim of their ancestors repeatedly sent messages through his messengers because he wanted to spare his people and his dwelling place.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: But they mocked Elohim’s messengers, despised his words, and made fun of his prophets until Yahweh became angry with his people. He could no longer heal them.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: So he had the Babylonian king attack them and execute their best young men in their holy temple. He didn’t spare the best men or the unmarried women, the old people or the sick people. Yahweh handed all of them over to him.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: He brought to Babylon each of the utensils from Elohim’s temple, the treasures from Yahweh’s temple, and the treasures of the king and his officials.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: They burned Elohim’s temple, tore down Jerusalem’s walls, burned down all its palaces, and destroyed everything of value.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The king of Babylon took those who weren’t executed to Babylon to be slaves for him and his sons. They remained captives until the Persian Empire began to rule.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This happened so that Yahweh’s words spoken through Jeremiah would be fulfilled. The land had its years of rest and was made acceptable again. While it lay in ruins, the land had its 70 years of rest.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: The promise Yahweh had spoken through Jeremiah was about to come true in Cyrus’ first year as king of Persia. Yahweh inspired the king to make this announcement throughout his whole kingdom and then to put it in writing.
verses.speaker: Narrator

verses.text: This is what King Cyrus of Persia says: Yahweh Elohim of heaven has given me all the kingdoms of the world. And he has ordered me to build a temple for him in Jerusalem (which is in Judah). May Yahweh Elohim be with all of you who are his people. You may go.
verses.speaker: Narrator
